search_result.title: Delaware groups are targeting Black maternal health with stress relief
search_result.text:
Ebony Jones knows all too well the stress of having a baby.

From routine experiences like nausea to attending too many doctor's appointments to count, she remembers how much of a toll it can take on the mind, as well as the body.

The Wilmington mom of six also had to contend with being a Black mother, something that research has shown adds others stressors – like going to the doctor and having to fight for equal treatment because they don't listen or are dismissive of pain.

By many accounts, Lashawn Norton has achieved the American dream.

She is a married mother of four children, an entrepreneur, a nonprofit founder and a leader often sought for speaking engagements.

Before these accolades, Norton was pregnant in 2015 with her fourth child and was being held at Baylor Women's Correctional Institution awaiting sentencing for a robbery conviction. She gave birth to a son on June 21, 2015.

search_result.title: Staffing shortages reveal needs in Sussex County women's health ...
search_result.text:
More than 700 pregnant women walk through the doors of La Red Health Center in Georgetown over the course of a year.

Often the women who come to this large beige building with red lettering do not speak English. As many as 85% of them do not have any insurance because of their immigration status. And it’s common for pregnant women to show up to their first prenatal appointment already late in their pregnancy or with high-risk conditions that were never addressed.

Yet these women know that when they come to La Red, they will be cared for.

Between a rapidly growing population and the ever-present needs of an often undocumented or underinsured immigrant community, Sussex County has long recognized a demand to grow its health care infrastructure.

search_result.title: Here's how Delaware can help children in poverty: Delaware Voice
search_result.text:
Andrea Swan

Special to the News Journal

Children do not choose to be born poor.

When poverty begins at birth, it can affect health; school readiness and test scores; social skills and problem behaviors; substance use/abuse; and police involvement.

Basically, poor children start life at a deficit. The Coalition for Delaware’s Kids wants to change this.

Read more:Coalition says $55M in extra revenue should fund Delaware's neediest kids

To this end, on Dec. 5, the Coalition announced its plan to use the more than $50 million in assets that the state suddenly holds.

The Coalition includes community leaders, government, and religious organizations, including: Network Delaware, the Metropolitan Wilmington Urban League, the Delaware Attorney General’s Office, the Delaware PTA, the United Way, and many others. We are urging the creation of a four-year “Hope Trust” to increase support for the state’s children most affected by poverty.

Editorial:Until budget is fixed, be careful with spending promises

Key points of the trust include:

● Home visitation programs for infants and toddlers in low-income homes: Delaware used to lead the nation in enacting the Nurse Family Partnership Program, but in recent years the program has been drastically reduced. The Coalition proposes that the state use $10 million to greatly expand aid to children of first time, low-income mothers.

● Expanded Pre-K enrollment for 3- and 4-year-olds: Nationally, 43.1 percent of 4-year-olds are enrolled in Pre-K programs. In Delaware, it is only 21.4%. The Coalition suggests the state spend $10 million to expand pre-school enrollment through the Early Childhood Assistance Program.

● Increased financial support for high-poverty elementary schools: A small number of elementary schools in Delaware educate a very high percentage of children from lower socioeconomic backgrounds. The Coalition advises the state to issue $10 million in grants to the ten elementary schools where 70% of students live below the poverty line.

● Expanded after-school and summer programs for low-income students: after-school and summer programs that provide a structured and safe environment outside of regular school hours have many benefits. Sadly, there are few such programs for kids from low-income homes that cannot afford to pay enrollment fees. The Coalition wants the state to use $10 million to dramatically expand the grant program for after-school and summer programs, with a special focus on programs for students twelve and older.

● Improved re-entry services for juveniles leaving the correctional system: Delaware’s juvenile repeat offender rate is extremely high – nearly 80% of kids who spend time in correctional facilities commit new crimes upon release. The Coalition urges the state to spend $10 million in grants to non-profit organizations that provide cognitive behavioral therapy and family-centered programs.

● Addressing juvenile substance abuse: Delaware’s opioid crisis involves many high school-aged kids. The Coalition recommends that the state spend $2 million to provide the initial operating costs for a recovery high school.

● Use of the Centers for Disease Control’s data sharing plan: The CDC has recommended that Delaware take advantage of its data systems to provide broad-based, early help to Wilmington youths who might later become violent offenders. The Coalition proposes that the state spend $2 million to establish CDC’s data system.

By providing quality programs and services, the ill effects of childhood adversity can be eased, and in some cases avoided completely. The state has the chance to ensure that more of Delaware’s children have the continual support they need in order to thrive. By adopting the plan of the Coalition for Delaware’s Kids, the state can begin to lessen the impact of poverty and help the state’s most vulnerable residents.

Andrea Swan lives in Wilmington, is a social worker and co-coordinator for Coalition for Delaware’s Kids.

search_result.title: Letters: My mom already birthed two babies 'another one was more ...
search_result.text:
Letters to the Editor

Note from Opinion Editor Amelia Robinson: News of a leaked draft of a Supreme Court decision that would overturn Roe v. Wade continued to generate response from Dispatch readers. Below is a sampling of responses.

My mom nearly died of abortion

My mother died this year at age 93. She had been my best friend.

I chose to forgo motherhood, but many decades ago, before Roe vs. Wade, I accidentally became pregnant when I was a junior in college.

I wanted an abortion but they were not legal in the state where I lived; I could have traveled some distance to obtain one, however.

More:If abortion is banned in Ohio, seekers would have to drive 157 to 269 miles| Opinion

Soon after I was aware that I was pregnant, I sat down with my parents and began to tell them of my pregnancy.

Almost before I could finish my sentence, a loud, blood-curdling scream came from my mother as she jumped up and flew into her bedroom, where she cried like I had never before heard her cry.

I looked at my father. He slowly explained that after I was born, at the same age as I was, she had had an illegal abortion. “She nearly died from it.”

More:Letters: I remember 'horror stories of girls who died in desperate circumstances' before Roe

Now I understood. She had already birthed two babies less than a year apart and another one was more than she could take.

So I continued with the pregnancy, dropped out of college, lived with strangers until the birth, and more painful than the birth itself, was the shaming of my family, which resulted in years of low self-esteem.

When the child was born, I surrendered it for adoption.

Aileen Hall, The Plains

Abortion wouldn't be issue if you didn't get pregnant

Concerning your article on the South Dakota woman who, upon discovering that she was pregnant and being shocked by it, drove all the way to Minnesota, braving icy roads, etc, to obtain abortion pills and then crying in her car because she felt like she had just lost a pregnancy. Wow.

Opinion in your inbox:Sign up for the Conversation newsletter

Couldn't the whole thing have been simply avoided by either her or her husband using birth control?

It's like the old expression, "If you don't want to go to Chicago, don't get on the bus."

Jeff Danison, Delaware

This is not a political fight, it is fight for basic human rights

As a woman, I believe the right to have an abortion is vital for a woman and her body.

For many years, abortion rights have been fought for and against. This fight for basic human rights has been turned into a political debate and women are surrounded by people who are trying to control their body.

If a woman is raped and becomes pregnant and cannot support the baby, abortion is a way to help the woman.

What if a woman is ill and her life becomes threatened if she were to proceed with the pregnancy? Well, abortion is a way to save her life. If the baby had life-threatening illnesses and won’t survive birth, abortion is a way to relieve the baby of this pain. This is not a political fight, this is a fight of basic human rights.

More:Letters: Jean Schmidt wants to keep women 'barefoot, pregnant' in the kitchen

There are many easy ways you can help save abortion rights and help fight for this cause. Simply telling friends and family and even posting on social media gets the word out! Supporting abortion funds can play a critical role in helping woman who can’t afford abortions and can also help provide other resources for them as well.

The SisterSong: Women of Color Reproductive Justice Collective is the largest national multi-ethnic reproductive justice collective. A great way is also to get connected with Planned Parenthood. You can make a difference.

Samantha Louise Wilson, Hilliard

Will pro-life people adopt unwanted babies?

The suspected overturning of Roe v. Wade the U.S. Supreme Court will unleash a wave of pontification from people who claim to be pro-life. The issue is clearly defined. Who should decide whether a fetus should be carried to term—politicians or women with unwanted pregnancies?

It’s easy to claim that a fetus’ heartbeat means that a viable being exists. However, being pro-choice does not make anyone pro-abortion. There is far more to life than simply being born. A child deserves more than a life in an orphanage.

Because of the Supreme Court’s ruling, millions of unwanted children will be born and placed for adoption or in facilities for babies with serious mental or physical defects. How many pro-life people will be willing to adopt them? Time will tell but wise people will be skeptical of pro-lifers’ willingness to practice what they preach.

Dick Graham, Worthington

Share your thoughts:How to submit a letter to the editor for The Columbus Dispatch

Mother need help not choice

So much is written about the possible repeal of Roe.

Look at what is written and the pictures of those opposing this. They have so much anger and resentment about losing control of their bodies. What about the body of the infant inside them? Give him/her a chance to live.

Yes, a decision to have the baby can be tough; life itself is tough, but is worth it. Those who advocate for a complete ban on abortions see that this life needs protected in the mom and allowed to be born.

More:Who gets abortions in Ohio? Unmarried, twenty-somethings in their first trimester.

These same people are some of the most generous, self-giving people around.

Many of these people help provide maternity clothes, baby clothes, diapers. They donate these items directly to pregnancy care centers, food/clothing banks and other places that moms and families can go for help.

More:Opinion: Pregnancy centers not 'fake,' they serve women exploited by Planned Parenthood

There are many crisis pregnancy centers , funded in large part by pro-lifers, that have certified staff and trained counselors, ready to assist and encourage moms to not have an abortion, make them aware of resources that are available to get the material assistance that they need, where they can get needed medical care, etc.

Many of the pro-lifers are involved in the community and advocate and assist with organizations that help moms and babies. You don’t have to believe me – check it out on the internet, Google "diaper donations," Google "pregnancy assistance," Google "maternity clothes donations." You’ll find a lot of information out there and, I bet that a lot of it is done by pro-lifers and others encouraging moms to have their baby and not abort.

I have one question: How many of the above services and assistances are offered by those advocating for choice so that the moms don’t have to abort their child?

Life is beautiful and precious – let's all work together toward a world that respects all life and enables all to achieve their potential.

More:Democratic lawmakers want to protect abortion access by amending Ohio's constitution

We’ve gone through almost 50 polarizing years with Roe. Instead of trying to keep it in place and trying to protect a woman’s "right to choose," why not help them so they don’t have to choose abortion, offer them assistance to bring their child into the world, support rape crisis centers, adoption services, etc. Their child needs life to achieve his/her potential and help make this a better world.

Tom Crosby, Columbus

Dream on! Pro-lifers won't help pregnant women

In his May 6 column, "I'm glad Trump's legacy could be the end of Roe v. Wade," Patrick T. Brown hopes that after Roe v. Wade is ended, "pro-life" conservatives will turn their attention to championing social and economic public policies that make parents' lives easier and ensure that women in crisis pregnancies will have the material and social support necessary to support a child.

Sure, they will. Dream on.

Patti Liszkay, Gahanna

Banning abortion won't stop it

Prohibition had a lot of unintended consequences and it didn’t work because people wanted to drink alcohol.

The majority of people back legal abortion and a short-sighted court decision taking away individual rights would open up a Pandora’s box of consequences as well. But court extremists are putting all that at risk if Alito’s majority opinion stands.

Susan B. West, Athens

Supreme Court of the 1600s making decisions

I wanted to wish the “leaker” of the Supreme Court document to overturn Roe a very happy Mother’s Day.

I imagine the person to be a supporter of women who wanted us to see an unpolished version of how the 4-5 members of the court really think about women.

The document relies on the beliefs of a man from the 1600s who still wanted women burned at the stake.

The document reveals those members have no understanding of the incredibly difficult decisions normal women make daily about budgets, housing, violence against them and their children, a lack of safe neighborhoods and often safe water.

More:Abortion still legal in Ohio – for now – as country waits for U.S. Supreme Court decision

Women deal with legislative decisions about taxes and childcare that could support them but get voted down. And, yes, women make difficult health care decisions for themselves and their families.

So, thank you, leaker.

The disdain from those 4-5 members is no longer able to hide behind a sanitized version from a protected sanctimonious group whose small-minded and biased decision making needed to be revealed and not protected.

Penny Winkle, Columbus

What about the unborn child's father?

You can’t argue with the true believers in the sanctity of the unborn. Yet the same people show no equivalent concern for the needs of the unwanted born and mother including, at first, medical issues and a safe stress free environment. Oddly, nothing is said about the responsibility of the father. Some hypocrisy here?

More:Letters: 'Don't like abortions? Don't get one.' Saving babies doesn't equal killing moms.

The mother and child’s vicissitudes of a compulsory birth are well-documented, including developing medical consequences, family tension and lost opportunities in education and inevitably, career. A descent into welfare is common. This, in turn, must have serious economic consequences to society in general. It must cost plenty. Oddly, not mentioned.

Beware, there will be hue and cry how you cannot put a dollar cost on such things.

Gideon Fraenkel, Columbus

'Fear and misogyny' ruling court

Repealing Roe v. Wade has never been about “saving babies.”

If it were, we would have universal healthcare, affordable childcare, strong anti-poverty programs and more.

Repealing Roe v. Wade is about some people’s fear and misogyny, their belief that women are too “hysterical” and incapable of making good decisions, their conviction that women must never be the equal of men, and their need to punish, control, and regulate them.

Repealing Roe v Wade is about insulting and demeaning women and keeping them in their place.

Mark Hiser, Dublin

Saying abortion 'about the Constitution' is 'chilling and cruel'

In her recent letter to the editor, Suzanne Purdy wrote that “overturning Roe v. Wade is not about women’s bodies or even about abortion but about the Constitution.”

Her words would be laughable if they weren’t so casually chilling and cruel.

Pat Semmelman, Columbus

search_result.title: Amy Gonzalez, brother David Matusiewicz to be sentenced for ...
search_result.text:
Jessica Masulli Reyes

The (Wilmington, Del.) News Journal

WILMINGTON, Del. — Nearly four dozen family members and friends of the two women murdered in the New Castle County Courthouse in 2013 let out a sigh of relief Thursday after the shooter’s adult children were sentenced to life in prison on federal cyberstalking charges.

The group packed a federal courtroom in Wilmington for the sentencing of David Matusiewicz, 48, and Amy Gonzalez, 43. Their intention was to impress upon the judge the serious danger faced by the public and the three daughters of Matusiewicz and his deceased ex-wife if life sentences were not handed down.

“The Matusiewiczes will never stop until they have my sisters,” Katherine Moffa, the older half-sister of the three girls, said in an emotional plea to the judge. “Please make them go away so we can get the justice we deserve.”

Memories linger one year after Del. courthouse shooting

U.S. District Court Judge Gerald Austin McHugh heard those pleas — and, while giving both defendants the maximum sentence, said childhood should be a time of innocence and security.

"Punishment of these defendants, severe punishment, was absolutely warranted," Acting U.S. Attorney David Weiss said. "This was the only way that the court was able to protect the Matusiewicz children and anyone else who happened to draw the ire of the Matusiewiczes."

This case marked the first time in the United States that a defendant was convicted and sentenced under the federal cyberstalking resulting in death statute.

Thursday’s sentencing stemmed from a heinous double murder that rocked the legal community and the state.

On Feb. 11, 2013, Thomas Matusiewicz shot and killed his ex-daughter-in-law, Christine Belford, and her friend, Laura "Beth" Mulford, as they walked into New Castle County Courthouse for a child support hearing. Thomas Matusiewicz exchanged gunfire with police before killing himself.

After the shooting, prosecutors accused Thomas Matusiewicz’s widow, Lenore Matusiewicz, and two children of waging a vicious campaign to harass and stalk Belford and their daughters in the three years leading up to her death. Federal prosecutors have pointed to a web of emails, letters and other correspondence that attacked Belford’s character and accused her of sexually abusing their oldest daughter, a fact the government, judge and eldest daughter said was not true.

“In the process, they shattered lives,” Weiss said. “They left permanent scars in this community.”

A Delaware jury found the three guilty in July of various charges, including cyberstalking, conspiracy and interstate stalking. The legal standard for doing so was somewhat untested.

To find the defendants’ guilty of cyberstalking resulting in death, the jury didn’t have to find that the family knew of Thomas Matusiewicz’s killing plan, only that they could have reasonably foreseen, based on their own conduct, that Thomas Matusiewicz, considered a co-conspirator, would shoot Belford.

Attorneys for all three defendants have maintained that none knew of his plan.

McHugh, in handing down the sentence on Thursday, said that while David Matusiewicz likely foresaw the courthouse murder, Amy Gonzalez had no deliberate intent of murder but should have been aware of looming violence that was going to occur.

Gonzalez, who the prosecution has characterized as the “propaganda director” for the harassment and stalking conspiracy, was sentenced to life in prison despite that difference.

Before hearing her fate, Gonzalez stood before the judge and offered a tearful apology to the victims. The former nurse from Texas asked for mercy for her, her husband and their 10-year-old daughter.

“My heart goes out to all of [the victims],” she said. “I cry for them every day and pray for them every day.”

She said she only wanted the best for her nieces, but should have let law enforcement investigate her “suspicions” of child abuse, rather than harassing Belford via the Internet.

McHugh said he “anguished” over the sentencing of Gonzalez, but ultimately found that she was “inextricably interwoven” in the offenses and lacks the moral compass to ever be let out of prison.

“I hope you will continue to pray for these children and their futures,” he said.

David Matusiewicz, wearing a green prison jumpsuit, decided not to speak at his sentencing but provided the judge with a written statement.

His attorneys, Edson Bostic and Dina Chavar, told The News Journal after the sentencing that they will file an appeal on his behalf soon.

Lenore Matusiewicz, who is terminally ill, was sentenced to life in prison last Friday at an emergency, bedside hearing at a hospital in Philadelphia. Her attorney has already filed notice of appeal.

Because this is the first conviction for cyberstalking resulting in death, the case could be heavily litigated on appeal in the coming years.

The Matusiewicz family's saga began in 2006 when David Matusiewicz, a Newark optometrist, and Belford divorced. The ensuing bitter custody battle over their three children took an unusual turn when David and Lenore Matusiewicz took the girls on what was supposed to be a two-week trip to Disney World in 2007.

They instead headed to Central America, leading to a year-and-a-half-long international manhunt that finally ended when they were found living in a mobile home in the tiny Nicaraguan village of Catalina.

The girls were returned to the United States and reunited with Belford. David and Lenore Matusiewicz pleaded guilty to their roles in the kidnapping and were sentenced to prison.

Federal prosecutors have accused David Matusiewicz of launching the family's campaign against Belford from his prison cell in 2009.

“Christine Belford had no chance, zero chance,” said Assistant U.S. Attorney Jamie McCall. “They literally suffocated her.”

Six months after David Matusiewicz was released from prison, he and his parents traveled from Texas to Delaware for a child support hearing with Belford at the New Castle County Courthouse, where the shooting occurred.

“This was the place … that people come to peacefully resolve their disputes,” Weiss said. “The Matusiewiczes used this place, as Judge McHugh noted, as a bait, as a lure. They chose this as the place they would carry out the execution.”

Weiss said he hopes the life sentences will provide some comfort to Belford’s daughters. Many noted during the sentencing that for their protection they have been isolated from all of their friends and family, including their half-sister Moffa.

"This is not a victimless crime by any means," McHugh said.

Follow Jessica Masulli Reyes on Twitter: @JessicaMasulli

search_result.title: Paid parental leave for state workers passes Delaware General ...
search_result.text:
State workers scored a victory Wednesday when the Delaware General Assembly approved a bill granting them 12-weeks of paid family leave.

The Senate voted 16 to 4 to provide what remains a relatively rare benefit in the United States. The House passed the bill earlier this month.

The measure now heads to Gov. John Carney, who opened the year by pledging his support for the bill. He and his wife Tracey also recently penned a column on the subject for Mother's Day.

Carney on Tuesday said women will make up a large portion of the state's new hires as a large portion of the state's workforce reaches retirement age.

"This benefit will be great for those women, great for us in terms of attracting them and great for the babies and children as well," he said. "It's the right thing to do for families, it's the right thing to do for the women who work for the state of Delaware and it's the right thing to do for our state."

The passage of House Bill 3 also was cheered by the Delaware State Education Association, the largest union that represents state workers.

"We shouldn’t be forcing people to choose between taking care of a new child and being able to put food on the table or paying the bills” said DSEA President Mike Matthews. “And, not only does this legislation support new parents, but it also helps in the recruitment and retention of educators and state workers.”

First proposed by Rep. Debra Heffernan, D-Bellefonte, in 2015, the bill will allow state workers employed for at least a year to take up to three months of paid maternity or paternity leave within a year of their child's birth. Parents who adopt a child ages 6 and younger also will be eligible.

"It was three years of hard work and really a group effort," Heffernan said. "I think it's a fantastic benefit for all state workers."

The Office of Comptroller General estimates about 1,000 state workers — including public, charter and vo-tech school employees — will take advantage of the paid leave offered by the bill each year.

The total cost to the state is estimated at about $4 million per year. School district's also will have to spend a combined $1.26 million per year on substitute teachers, the comptroller reported.

That cost raised concerns among some lawmakers, including Senate Majority Leader Gary Simpson, R-Milford.

"I fully appreciate the social aspects of this bill," he said. "But I think this body is asked to look a little deep into whether it is fiscally sound and I've got to say this is probably the most fiscally irresponsible bill that I've seen in my 20 years in the Senate."

He also questioned whether the bill might contribute to a serious staffing shortage in the Department of Correction, while the executive director of the Delaware Association of School Administrators said she fears the legislation will add to a long-standing shortage among substitute teachers.

Simpson was joined by three other Republicans in opposing the bill, including Sens. Gerald Hocker of Ocean View, Dave Lawson of Marydel and Brian Pettyjohn of Georgetown.

With the bill's passage, Delaware becomes the sixth state, along with Washington D.C. to offer some form of paid family leave to public sector workers.

The federal Family Medical Leave Act allows state — and most private employees — to take 12 weeks of leave to care for a newborn. But the law does not require employers to pay those workers during that time.

Heffernan's legislation does not impact private businesses in Delaware, although some major employers here already offer paid family leave, including JPMorgan Chase, Sallie Mae, Barclays and Amazon.

Only three states — California, New Jersey and Rhode Island — and the District of Columbia require private employers to provide paid family leave, including time off to care for sick family members.

Massachusetts lawmakers approved legislation Tuesday that would allow all workers to take up to 12 weeks paid family leave and 20 weeks of medical leave.

The Delaware Senate on Tuesday also passed the first — and by far the largest — of several pieces in the state budget puzzle.

The $4.27 billion operating budget for fiscal year 2019 — 4 percent more than the current year — cleared the chamber with only Sen. Colin Bonini, R-Dover, casting a vote of opposition.

The bill, which includes the core of the state's spending plan for the coming year, now heads to the House for final approval.

The General Assembly has yet to consider a supplemental budget bill that includes bonuses for state workers that would bring to total spending growth to 5.2 percent. A bond bill that includes funding for capital projects and a Grant-in-Aid bill that provides taxpayer dollars to a more than 100 nonprofits have yet to be introduced.

search_result.title: 2024 tax season guide for new parents: Child Tax Credit, EITC ...
search_result.text:
If you recently had or adopted your first child, filing your taxes probably was not a top priority. But even if you're sleep-deprived and haven't left your home in months, you still had to find the time to prepare a return for 2023.

With a new child, your taxes will get more complicated. But the flip side is, you may qualify for a slew of new tax credits and deductions.

Here's what new parents need to know for the 2024 tax season and beyond:

Get a Social Security card for your child

The first order of business is to make sure your child has a Social Security number, said John Karls, a tax partner at Armanino, a national tax advisory firm. "You can't claim your child as a dependent on your tax return if they don't have a Social Security number."

Holiday deals: Shop this season’s top products and sales curated by our editors.

If you don't already have one for your child, you should apply now. But it could take a while for the Social Security Administration to verify your child's birth certificate and identity, so Karls recommends filing for a six-month tax extension while you wait.

More:Residents of this state pay $987,117 in lifetime taxes. Guess which one?

Tax season 2024:Can I claim my parents as dependents? This tax season, more Americans are opting in

Head of household status

If you're a single parent, for tax purposes you're considered the head of the household. That means you could claim a $20,800 standard deduction in 2023, versus a $13,850 standard deduction for single filers without dependents. In 2024, those deductions rise to $21,900 and $14,600.

There are also separate, more favorable tax brackets for heads of households.

Importantly, the IRS won't automatically recognize that you're a single parent and thereby qualify for head-of-household status. You'll have to manually check a box yourself, or inform your tax preparer.

If you're married and cover more than half of your child's expenses, you would also be considered a head of household, but only if you file separately from your spouse.

How much do you get back in taxes for a child?

Generally, people think having a child will automatically lower their tax bill or trigger a larger refund. But in many cases, it depends on your income. Lower-income taxpayers are generally eligible for more generous tax credits and deductions after having or adopting a child, said Jim Daniels, a CPA and managing director at UHY Advisors, a tax and consulting services firm.

Adoption tax credit

If you adopted a child in 2023, you might have been able to qualify for a credit of up to $15,950 in adoption-related expenses you incurred per child. This could include adoption-related attorney fees, adoption fees, traveling expenses and more. The credit increased to $16,810 in 2024.

To claim the full credit, your modified adjusted gross income, which is generally close to your adjusted gross income, must be below $239,230. After that, the credit phases out and is not available for people who have a modified gross adjusted income of $279,230. For 2024, those figures rise to $252,150 and $292,150.

The credit is not refundable, meaning if you don't owe any taxes, you won't be able to claim the credit. However, you can carry it forward to reduce your tax liability in the future.

How much is the Child Tax Credit this year? What are the qualifications?

If you became a parent in 2023, you could qualify for the Child Tax Credit if you had an adjusted gross income of less than $200,000 or less than $400,000 if you were filing a joint return with a spouse.

Child and dependent care credit income limit

If you are employed and pay for child care services, you may qualify for the Child and Dependent Care Tax Credit. To qualify, you must have earned income in 2023 and have work-related care expenses, among other rules. You can seek the credit for up to $3,000 of expenses for one child, $6,000 for two or more children. The actual credit is a percentage of those expenses. See IRS Publication 503 for the formulas.

EITC qualifications

Having a child could make you eligible for the Earned Income Tax Credit. If you have one child and your adjusted gross income was $46,560 (filing alone) or $53,120 (filing jointly with a spouse) in 2023, you could claim up to $3,995 in a refundable tax credit.

In 2024, using the same example, the income levels rise to $49,084 and $56,004, and the credit ranges up to $4,213.

Make adjustments to your W-4 withholding

Finally, if you haven't already, you should make sure to fill out a new W-4 form if you have an employer, to reflect that you now have a dependent. This will likely lower the refund you get next year, but it will increase the size of your paychecks going forward, Daniels said, because less money will be withheld.

search_result.title: Seaford saved its hospital, but what else did it lose in the merger?
search_result.text:
Dr. Joaquin Cabrera jokes that practically every family in Seaford owes him a baby.

The obstetrician estimates that he has delivered close to 4,000 babies in this small rural community in western Sussex County. Since moving to southern Delaware about 35 years ago, Cabrera can’t go to the grocery store or a sporting event without running into a patient. His children grew up here. His wife taught at a nearby school. He spent the past few decades making this town his home.

search_result.title: Wilmington residents are creating their own climate resilience hub
search_result.text:
Northeast residents were pummeled by Hurricane Ida's remnants in 2021, and the memories of flooding, displacement and panic remain fresh on the minds of many.

Resident organizers are launching "Northeast Rising," a team and climate resilience hub aimed at community engagement and climate-change-fueled disaster preparedness.

It aims to offer training, resources and safe shelter in the wake disaster — or during extreme summer heat.

Mud was caked up to their knees.

A mom, a dad, their little boy, an image of them walking up the street stays soaked in her mind. It joins displaced families packing local hotels, babies with diaper rashes, damp clothes and hungry faces. Months of new images, more people in need.

Stacey Henry remembers coming home exhausted each night after Hurricane Ida, after its remnants brought extreme flooding to her neighborhood in September 2021. She organized relief efforts; she disseminated supplies; she helped families find housing; she was recognized as a woman of the year. But the self-appointed people’s advocate also remembers more private moments, venting through a clutched phone.

“At night, I would literally go home and there was one friend of mine, she would just listen to me,” the Wilmington native remembered. “I just kept saying, I didn't know the name of it. I didn't know what to call it, but I have to build something.”

She would start keeping a list of those unhoused. She would spend hours cooking, bringing trays of pasta to hotels. She would start fielding calls from all over the city, frantically organizing food distribution, asking state officials if they'd buy diapers or dry socks. Days following the flooding were chaotic, and residents in the Northeast were terrified.

“I have to organize something,” Henry continued, recalling her evening musings. “So that when there's a disaster, there's a place or a group that can come in immediately, until the plans that they have in the file cabinets with dust on them are pulled out."

Memories of flooding, displacement and panic are still fresh on the minds of many residents in Wilmington's Northeast. Organizers who stepped up after this storm never want to see the same devastation again. Or, face it unprepared.

Today they hope to have the beginnings of an answer: a Delaware Resilience Hub.

Henry and other residents banded to launch a climate resilience hub, focused on community engagement and climate-change-fueled disaster readiness. The team has found a funding partner in Philadelphia-based Green Building United, alongside other partners across Delaware.

Packed into Wilmington’s PAL Center, a community center and the base for the new outfit, organizers marked an official launch April 29 with information sessions, workshops and free emergency preparedness kits. It's a first for the neighborhood, Henry said, and a first for Delaware.

She hopes the vision expands to more Wilmington neighborhoods.

‘I wouldn’t take no for an answer’:Lifelong Wilmington resident recognized for advocacy

Intensifying future storms, accelerating sea-level rise, extreme heat — Henry knows the brunt of disasters is borne by under-resourced, vulnerable neighborhoods like her own. Riverside, 11th Street Bridge and Eastside neighborhoods were some of the most affected by Ida.

Now, a vision of preparedness is taking shape. And step one might be getting people's attention.

Have a story to tell? Delaware Online/The News Journal is placing special emphasis on reporting about heat impact this summer, as part of an ongoing Perilous Course project across USA TODAY Network Northeast examining the human-centered damage and risks driven by the climate crisis. Reach out: kepowers@gannett.com.

Understanding a vision for resiliency in Wilmington

Residents peered into their buckets.

Flashlights, first aid kits, bottled water, blankets, rope, more packed against smooth blue plastic. Many residents who had to replace personal documents just two years ago looked down at plastic sleeves made to store copies of birth certificates and other identification. Over 30 attendees filed into the center, perched on North Market Street’s higher ground, and were handed these stuffed kits.

“Grab the bucket while they're grabbing you,” Henry put it simply. Her team believes many neighbors would be much better off if they had supplies like these during Ida.

The kits are an early step for the group, Northeast Rising. It meets aims for training on first aid, evacuation routes and more for members and interested residents. Unlike working alone in a makeshift hotel office in 2021, Henry and her team want residents to know there’s a place to go in the wake of disaster.

The hub boasts communication, resources, dry clothes and cool air. And it would support more than post-disaster recovery.

Even on the soggy April morning, Henry knows summer is fast approaching. Core to the hub’s plan, she described, will also be offering a place to escape a different threat.

Still flooding their neighborhood, still sweeping between homes and across pavement, already claiming more lives than any other weather-related cause in the U.S. — it’s heat.

“It’s a place for them to be for the hours that the heat index is dangerously high,” Henry said. Heat index, or how hot a day "feels," combines both temperature and humidity. When it's more humid, it's much harder for the body to cool off by sweating.

Northeast Rising plans to open the air-conditioned gym when conditions call for it, providing water and food. Research shows the brunt of increasing heat will not be felt equally. It will fall on households with lower incomes, renters without access to efficient air conditioning, those facing homelessness and others most vulnerable.

Urban heat island?Not all Wilmington neighborhoods experience the same summer heat. Here’s why.

Back in the PAL, hardly able to keep still as she watched residents listen to the Aug. 29 speakers, Henry knows she has yet to see anything quite like her vision in the First State. She called it a catalyst.

But, Northeast is just one pocket of Delaware’s largest city.

“This is small,” she said.

“It's large for me, but it may be small for the city. I don't have money to do what I need to do — but I've started to bring awareness to the support that we're going to need from the community, from the government, from everyone, to make this hub one of many.”

Storms like these...

Hurricane Ida’s remnants brought floods to a 20-block radius of the city.

A maximum crest of 23.1 feet — measured near Rockford Park on the morning of Sept. 2 — had the Brandywine set a new record, as previously reported.

Floodwaters lifted cars, swallowed bridges. Emergency responders rescued over 200 people from homes, wading through the streets in boats. Displaced residents struggled for months to find housing, as city and state response came under fire.

A changing climate will play a role in the prevalence of these strong storms. A warming planet draws more water into the atmosphere, contributing to heavier storms, and a rising sea.

It’s everywhere:Sea-level rise is damaging much more than beach homes and East Coast shoreline

Looking back:Displaced by September floods, Wilmington residents still living in shelters, cars in January

From the Chesapeake to Massachusetts bays, Ida brought surges several feet above typical high tide levels. Rising seas can spell problems for more inland communities, too, as high tides and strengthened storm surges push water higher in nearby rivers during extreme storms, and into floodplains.

Rivers across the region broke records. Higher tides push back on these rivers, preventing flow back into the sea — while fresh water from extreme rainfall starts stacking up.

If it can’t drain into watersheds, it will find new routes. Without regard for neighborhoods.

Dangerous moisture can be more insidious, too.

For every 1-degree Celsius temperatures rise, according to First Street, the air holds about 7% more water vapor. This contributes to more humid days, with a higher likelihood of hazardous heat.

Heat claims more lives than flooding and hurricanes combined.

Dense urban areas feel heat exacerbated, as concentrations of dark materials like asphalt, steel and brick trap heat between buildings and streets. A difference of a few degrees of extreme heat can affect the body’s ability to regulate, and extended exposure compounds stress on organs. Those with respiratory illnesses, diabetes and obesity maintain the highest risk.

Wilmington already sees an average of seven more days a year over 90 degrees than it did 50 years ago.

The state is tied with Arizona as the fourth-fastest warming state based on temperature trends since 1970. Average temperatures in Delaware are projected to increase 2.5 to 4.5 degrees by 2050, from 2012 averages. That could rise up to 8 degrees by 2100, in the worst emissions scenario, according to the Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control.

Historically just one day above 100 degrees would be rare in Delaware, coming about once a year, if that. But by 2050, the state’s Climate Action Plan warns of two to eight each year, alongside projections of up to five nights with temperatures above 80.

The perilous list continues.

This more extreme future will likely demand physical adaptation, according to a national report on hazardous heat, as well as planning for emergency heat events, such as checking on residents, creating more cooling centers and ensuring people can reach them.

That means communities and governments unfamiliar with extreme heat will have to adapt and prepare for it.

“The conversation needs to be about people,” Henry said, back in Wilmington. “It’s about our climate and what we're going to do to prepare ourselves for what's coming.”

A highly contentious proposal that some say puts doctors in an ethical dilemma is back on the table in Delaware.

search_result.title: Letters to the editor: Flawed views on assisted suicide bill
search_result.text:
Letters to the editor

Flawed views on assisted suicide bill

There is no tangible evidence to support Dr. Callister's claims in his piece, “Compelling reasons to oppose Delaware assisted suicide legislation.”

I have worked as a physician assistant for seven years. I have taken care of many patients suffering from terminal illnesses; some would have appreciated the option of medical aid in dying to peacefully end their lives.



Insurers routinely make coverage determinations based on the efficacy of a drug or procedure. Many will decline to pay for experimental or unproven treatments. Reimbursement decisions are independent of whether or not a state has an authorized medical aid-in-dying law



None of Dr. Callister’s argument bears out when checked against the data and 30 years of combined experience across the six authorized states and the District of Columbia.



HB 160, Delaware’s proposed medical aid-in-dying legislation, would provide an option, not a mandate.



This is 2017. Patient-centered care has removed the ego from medicine and truly puts the patient’s wants and needs first.

My patients deserve this option if they deem it’s the right thing for themselves. I will keep fighting until we join the rest of the states that have already recognized this right.



Travis Fogelman

Wilmington

Right choice can be a hard choice

With a large deficit looming, it is time for our elected representatives to make the right choices.

No sales tax please. When I was 13 and living in New Jersey, they instituted a 2 percent sales tax, and said they would never raise it. The rest is history.

Once initiated, it is too easy to increase the rate to balance a budget. Sales taxes are also regressive and hurt the poor disproportionally.

Another two items are cop outs -- letting school districts raise taxes without taxpayer voting approval and cutting state costs by transferring them to the counties.

If our representatives don’t want to make the hard decisions themselves, then give the voters the power of referendum and put the hard choices on a ballot. Then any angry voters can’t blame the elected officials.

Al Katz

Bear

Media remains on the left

It's getting so bad, there are no longer facts.

Dana Milbank, in the Washington Post, questions and degrades Trump's character.

So if I say “Milbank's opinion is full of leftist bias and lacks any factual backing,” Milbank responds by calling me a liar.

Does my opinion make me liar? This is exactly what happened in the Trump/Comey interaction. Trump says the “FBI is poorly managed and lacks leadership.” Comey says “That's a lie.” Media (USA TODAY, Milbank, et.al.) reacts, saying “Trump is a liar.”

Mr. Milbank, who is being defamed here?

Similarly, NSA authorities, as well as Comey, confirm Russia tried to interfere with our elections. To my knowledge no facts have been presented publicly, except for Hillary's excuse for losing, that confirm Russia actually interfered.

We have certainly influenced foreign elections and in fact didn't Obama just declare support for Macron in the French election?

Jerry Emerson

Dover

Don't advocate sin taxes

I cannot believe the new rash of letters and articles to The News Journal advocating the raising of current taxes and adding new ones to accommodate the state's fiscal shortage.

And typically, these views are justifying taxes on cigarettes, soda, alcohol, as they are viewed as a morally backward.

I cannot believe that people think this will solve the shortfall. It is not the means to an end. It is just another reason to stick it to the working people. I smoke, drink soda and enjoy a six pack on a Friday night. And I have no children.

Would I advocate a one-time tax on child births, say $ 2000.per child, because that would not affect me and put the tax burden on others ?

No, because that would be short sighted and selfish, just like those who advocate putting the tax burden on others who enjoy certain legally obtainable products.

With the justification that they are unhealthy? Please, already. Any state's taxes fall into a bottomless well that is never quenched.

Shame on those who want taxes raised or created and justify them by adding moral or health implications.

Craig Fazekas

Milford

search_result.title: Compelling reasons to oppose Delaware assisted suicide legislation
search_result.text:
T. Brian Callister

As a physician who deals daily with terminal patients, I can say that HB 160 is bad policy for many reasons. Here are five:

First, contrary to what proponents say, legalizing assisted suicide actually limits your choices and access to healthcare.

Once assisted suicide becomes a medical option, it will be the cheapest option and provide incentive for insurers to save money by denying treatment. I had two patients from Oregon and California, states which have legalized assisted suicide, who were denied treatment.

They were not even “terminal” as long as they could receive the life-saving treatment we asked for. But there were denied coverage and offered assisted suicide pills instead. Neither they, nor I, had requested the lethal drugs. Assisted suicide is not about freedom, autonomy, or choice – it limits choice and reduces your healthcare options.

"In the final analysis, economics, not the quest for broadened individual liberties or increased autonomy, will drive assisted suicide to the plateau of acceptable practice.” (Derek Humphry and Mary Clement, Freedom to Die, St. Martin’s Press (New York, 1998), page 313).

Second, the underlying premise that everyone will suffer horrible pain at the end of life is simply not true in 2017. No one has to die in pain in this day and age. If someone is suffering needlessly, frankly they need to change doctors. In fact, “pain” is not even in the top five reasons for committing assisted suicide, according to data in Oregon. The top reasons listed are “burden to family” and “loss of autonomy.”

Third, a physician’s ability to predict life expectancy in terminal illness is often not accurate – the medical literature shows the average margin of error is 50-70 percent.

Assisted suicide, like hospice, requires a physician to “certify” six months or less to live. Physicians are frequently wrong – I put people on hospice all the time, and I take them off all the time. Patients often live months and even years longer than we thought with a good quality of life.

J.J. Hanson of Patients Rights Action Fund, a retired Marine, husband, and father, has the same horrible brain cancer as Brittany Maynard, an advocate of medical aid for dying before her own death in 2014.

Hanson is now grateful he did not have access to suicide pills in the first few months of his illness. In an impulsive moment of depression, he may have taken them. Today, he has a second child on the way.

Fourth, assisted suicide puts too much power in a doctor's hands and corrupts the medical profession.

We all know that doctors exercise a lot of influence with their patients, especially when important health decisions are being made.

Jeanette Hall was considering doctor prescribed suicide in Oregon, but her doctor said no and encouraged treatment.

Some 17 years later she is an oft-cited opponent of assisted suicide. "if my doctor had believed in assisted suicide, I would be dead," she said.

Finally, doctor shopping is a real danger if assisted suicide becomes law. Elder abuse is rampant in America. Nothing in the proposed assisted suicide law will prevent an interested party from looking for a doctor who will prescribe death if another doctor says “no."

In Oregon, 88 percent of the cases of doctor assisted suicides were “helped” in finding a doctor who would prescribe lethal drugs by the pro-assisted suicide group Compassion and Choices.

Assisted suicide is an affront to human dignity on every level and should be vigorously opposed by the people of Delaware and their elected representatives.

T. Brian Callister, M.D., is a board certified internal medicine specialist and hospitalist who is nationally recognized as an expert in both acute care medicine and the post-acute continuum. He practices in Nevada.

search_result.title: 'Death with dignity' law may be introduced
search_result.text:
Jon Offredo, and Jonathan Starkey

Dee Whildin says her husband, Frank, died a horrible death.

The Korean War veteran struggled with extreme seizures and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, a lung condition that restricted his breathing, forcing him to gasp for air.

As his health declined, Frank Whildin refused treatments and, under extreme pain, asked time and again why his doctors and nurses would not let him die, Dee Whildin says.

Frank Whildin finally died in October after years of pain.

"Nobody else should go through what my husband went through," Dee Whildin said. "I can accept my husband's death, but I cannot accept how he died."

Whildin is now aiding an effort to legalize physician-assisted suicide in Delaware. The debate over whether physicians should be allowed to prescribe lethal drugs to terminally ill patients is likely to reach Legislative Hall this spring.

Delaware Rep. Paul Baumbach, D-Newark, is preparing a measure that would mirror Oregon's 18-year-old "death with dignity" law. Since that law was enacted in October 1997, doctors have written lethal prescriptions for 1,327 patients and 859 have died from taking the drugs, including 105 last year.

Baumbach has not introduced legislation, or circulated language broadly for co-sponsors. But he says Delawareans with a terminal illness, and six months or less to live according to a doctor, also should be allowed to take medicine that ends their life.

"It could take more than a year for this to happen," Baumbach said. "But I'm open to whatever the process permits. We have a process here (in Legislative Hall) and if it is not ready for it (the bill) yet, it's not ready for it."

"I think what we are ready for is this discussion," Baumbach said.

Delaware's Medical Society, which represents doctors, and religious groups are likely to oppose Baumbach's effort. It's unclear whether Delaware Gov. Jack Markell, a Democrat, is open to signing legislation that would allow Delawareans to seek a doctor's help in dying. Baumbach will have support of patient advocates when he introduces legislation in Dover.

Oregon, Vermont and Washington have laws allowing physician-assisted suicide. Court decisions in Montana and New Mexico also have allowed assisted suicide in those states. A spokeswoman for Markell said the governor has not spoken with Baumbach about his upcoming legislation.

"The governor looks forward to reviewing the legislation and hearing more from Rep. Baumbach about his proposal if it is introduced," spokeswoman Kelly Bachman said in an email.

Dr. Joanne Lynn, director of the Altarum Institute's Center for Elder Care and Advanced Illness in Washington, said state and federal lawmakers must broadly discuss ways to care for the elderly.

The idea of allowing the terminally ill to seek assistance in dying ignores that most elderly patients face progressive degrees of disability before dying, and are never offered a clear-cut diagnosis indicating how long they have to live.

Policymakers advocating for physician-assisted suicide should start by exploring ways to more effectively fund long-term care, and craft plans for making elderly patients comfortable, coordinating services like housing, transportation and access to food.

"We are not even discussing public policy on long-term care," Lynn said. "We sort of sweep it under the rug."

In a written statement, the Medical Society said it "strongly opposes any bill to legalize physician-assisted suicide or euthanasia, as these practices are fundamentally inconsistent with the physician's role as healer."

The Medical Society said doctors should "redouble" efforts to ensure that dying patients receive treatment that make them as comfortable as possible. Physicians should resist the natural tendency to withdraw physically and emotionally from their patients," the group said in its prepared statement. And training physicians should receive more education on advanced pain management techniques.

"The use of more aggressive comfort care measures, including greater reliance on hospice care, can alleviate the physical and emotional suffering that dying patients experience," the Medical Society's statement says.

Dr. Nancy Fan, president of the Medical Society, said end-of-life treatment should stop short, however, of assisting a patient in dying. "We want to provide them comfort and relief and make sure they don't feel like they have no options" Fan said. "Our role as healers makes it very difficult for us to proactively assist in the concept of ending someone's life."

Baumbach said his legislation will likely allow assisted suicide in cases where patient shave been told by doctor they have six months or less to live.

Only patients would be allowed to authorize the decision to pursue that course. Patients would have to request assisted suicide, receive education about the process, and wait through a "cooling period" before receiving the lethal drugs.

"This is not something to be taken lightly," Baumbach said. "It has to be an arduous process to make sure you are certain. It is irreversible."

Nicole Theis, president of the Delaware Family Policy Council, said the program would still "endanger vulnerable people who will be pressured with a duty to die," over the fear of becoming dependent on others.

Assisted suicide also would offer a cheaper alternative to end-of-life treatment, subjecting elderly patients to abuse, Theis said. Delaware should instead expand options for early hospice, train more palliative physicians, mobilize faith communities to help others, and increase funding for home health care, she said.

Sean Hebbel is program director at the Cancer Support Network of Delaware, where he helps coordinate support groups for cancer patients, some of whom are terminally ill. Hebbel said he has discussed assisted suicide with patients, but none have expressed an interest in seeking help dying, he said.

But Hebbel says patients who face a painful death should be allowed to choose when they die, so long as the program is strictly overseen and guarantees that patients are making the decision with a clear mind.

"If we as a society can value the process of dying, just as much as the process of living, well, that would be lovely," Hebbel said.

Contact Jon Offredo at (302) 678-4271, on Twitter @jonoffredo or at joffredo@delawareonline.com. Contact Jonathan Starkey at (302) 983-6756, on Twitter @jwstarkey or at jstarkey@delawareonline.com.

search_result.title: End of Life Options Act will bring peace to suffering people (opinion)
search_result.text:
Maria Matos

Maria Matos is president and CEO of the Latin American Community Center in Wilmington.

As leader of the Latin American Community Center in Wilmington, I have spent more than 25 years addressing the immediate needs and advocating for Latinos in Delaware.

Sadly, many of my Latino brothers and sisters in our state are needlessly suffering from terminal illnesses because they don’t have access to the full range of end-of-life care options. This includes the option that would allow terminally ill adults to peacefully end their suffering.

This issue is very personal to me. I was diagnosed with an aggressive type of breast cancer in 2005. I underwent two surgeries, aggressive rounds of chemotherapy and radiation.

For me, the radiation was the most difficult to bear. The room looked like a tomb, and smelled like burnt flesh.

Those challenges made me a stronger fighter. My painful journey with cancer reminded me that I had unfinished business to do. It allowed me the opportunity to become a stronger advocate for early intervention through prevention and screening for life within the Latino community and to lend a voice to those who cannot speak for themselves.

More of this debate

Pro: We should be able to write our own endings

Con:Assisted suicide undermines human dignity

While I am blessed today to call myself cancer free, I would want this compassionate option if my cancer ever came back.

I am pleased to know that the Delaware General Assembly is considering a bill that would allow terminally ill adults the option to request a doctor’s prescription for medication they can decide to take to die peacefully in their sleep if their suffering becomes unbearable.

That’s why I am formally endorsing the Ron Silverio/Heather Block Delaware End of Life Options Act sponsored by Rep. Paul Baumbach. This compassionate legislation would allow terminally ill people of Delaware to peacefully end needless, intolerable suffering at life’s end.

Hispanics nationwide overwhelmingly support state laws that authorize the option of medical aid in dying for terminally ill adults.

Thanks to support from Latinos like civil rights activist Dolores Huerta, today 69 percent of Hispanics nationwide support medical aid in dying. The iconic Huerta recently recorded online videos in English and Spanish to urge fellow Hispanics to support these compassionate laws.

I strongly believe mis hermanos [brothers and sisters] in Delaware should have the option when the time comes — to make the end-of-life care decisions that are right for them and their loved ones — in the final stages of a terminal illness.

I understand this end-of-life care option may not be for everyone. Many terminally ill people have different opinions about what decisions are right for them in the final stages of a terminal illness.

But when there is nothing else that medicine can do and it becomes impossible to provide relief from extreme suffering, we should allow a person the option to peacefully end their suffering.

As a Christian who respects other people’s faiths, I believe it is not for me to judge someone else. The harsh reality is that no matter how hard we try, we cannot escape the cycle of life and death.

My faith tells me that if the time comes when we can’t bear the suffering that afflicts us, a merciful God will understand that we all should have the option to die peacefully without unbearable suffering.

Maria Matos is the President and CEO of the Latin American Community Center in Wilmington.

search_result.title: Here's what Delaware can (and can't) say about its COVID-19 cases
search_result.text:
As the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in Delaware continues to climb and the first deaths have been reported, many residents are looking for answers.

"Could Delaware please provide more detailed info of what towns, within each county, that have confirmed cases of the virus?" asked Milton resident Cindy Black. "I’d like to know if any cases are in my town?

"Maybe this info could help flatten the curve?"

Others are asking: How many tests have been conducted? Does the state have enough ventilators?

Health officials say they are constrained by the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, and because of this, cannot provide any additional details of specific cases — including towns — because it could lead to a person being identified.

FIRST DEATH:Sussex County man becomes Delaware's 1st coronavirus death; health care workers infected

The state will also not say how many ventilators, masks and other protective gear Delaware hospitals have available or will need to have in the future. This comes as several states, including New York and Washington, are desperately trying to find ventilators to save the lives of the sickest.

Delaware residents are not alone in this lack of knowledge; other state health departments have provided similar information, or lack thereof.

Some public health experts and elected officials believe more information is needed for Delawareans to truly grasp the magnitude of this pandemic and act in the public interest.

"I trust that if you see a place or a business or a town or a hot spot, you are more likely to isolate yourself," said Newark state Rep. John Kowalko. "It took me awhile to appreciate that you have to stay in. It really is distressing and it is also necessary.

"The more people take it seriously," he said, "the more likely we are to face this hidden enemy."

What can the state tell us?

Almost half the confirmed COVID-19 cases in Delaware — 95 — are among people age 18 to 49, state officials said.

Fifty-three people from age 50 to 64 have the virus, while 62 people 65 years and older have been confirmed, as of March 28. Four children under the age of 17 have contracted it as well.

The youngest resident to get the virus is a 1-year-old, while the oldest is 90.

As of March 28, there were 214 confirmed cases of the coronavirus in Delaware — 130 in New Castle County, 25 in Kent County and 59 in Sussex County.

More women have coronavirus than men. Thirty-one people have been hospitalized in Delaware, while two other residents were hospitalized out of state, officials said. Eight are critically ill, while nine people have recovered from the coronavirus.

In the two weeks since the first coronavirus case was announced, the state has been providing regular updates. This often includes a breakdown by county, gender, a general age range and the number of people who are hospitalized and in critical condition.

In the past week, the state has updated its COVID-19 website about twice a day and then sent a media advisory near the end of each workday. State officials have also held press conferences and virtual town halls.

READ:Find out how much your stimulus check could be

When Delaware announced its first case on March 11, health officials revealed the man was over the age of 50, lived in New Castle County and was connected to the University of Delaware.

The university later announced the man was a faculty member.

The next couple of confirmed cases included an age range, gender, and county. And, when applicable, the state identified the patients as members of the University of Delaware community.

But as the number of cases grew, the health department stopped providing information for each case, instead offering general statistics for the total confirmed cases in Delaware.

For a while, the state also provided information about the number of people who were being tested. When commercial labs began testing for the coronavirus in Delaware, the state then started to announce only positive cases.

Dr. Karyl Rattay, the director of the Division of Public Health, said Thursday that the state's public health lab, as of March 25, had run 639 tests.

At the Delaware health care facility testing sites, a total of 2,617 samples had been collected as of March 25. This does not include any tests performed in emergency departments, inpatient units or primary care offices, she said.

READ:See which Delaware workers face the greatest coronavirus risk

The state does not have the results of many of these samples yet, Rattay said, and it's unclear how many of these samples are from Delaware residents. The state said it will provide more information about the number of test results in the coming days.

"We are working through some data sharing issues and once we have that information, we plan to be able to share that with you," she said.

As of March 28, five people have died due to complications from the virus. The first Delawarean to die from coronavirus was a 66-year-old Sussex County man, who had underlying health conditions and was critically ill.

On Thursday, officials said the man had died within the previous 72 hours and had the typical symptoms of COVID-19, including a fever. Their announcement came 18 hours after a 7:30 p.m. press release Wednesday announced four victims had recovered.

During a virtual town hall Friday, Gov. John Carney mentioned the man lived in the Dagsboro area.

When answering a question on the media call Thursday, one state official briefly mentioned that the man died in a Maryland hospital, but quickly said "out-of-state hospital."

When a reporter asked to confirm the man died in Maryland, state officials would not do so.

What won't the state tell us?

Due to HIPAA restrictions, state officials say they can't release any personal information on any individual case, including: name, address, city, underlying health condition, or dates of medical care, including date of death.

This information, health officials say, on its own and combined with other "information in the public space" could lead to a person being identified.

"DPH’s greatest responsibility is to protect the personal health information of every individual in our state," said Rattay, the director of the Division of Public Health. "And we take that responsibility incredibly seriously."

MORE:More sacrifices lie ahead for Delawareans as coronavirus continues to spread

Yet, the state routinely releases ages, counties and information about whether a patient had a flu shot or underlying conditions when announcing deaths from influenza.

Specifically, Rattay said the state can't identify patients' towns due to HIPAA restricting information for populations less than 20,000.

This applies to many Delaware towns, she said. The areas that exceed this population count are Wilmington, Dover, Newark, Bear and Middletown.

Around 1 p.m. Friday, the state updated its coronavirus website to include two graphs indicating where COVID-19 cases are by Delaware ZIP code. The first graph includes data from March 8 to March 14, while the second covers from March 8 to March 21.

The state was able to reveal the first confirmed case's connection to the University of Delaware because the community exceeded this number.

Delaware officials have declined to provide specific information about the number of ventilators and other medical supplies currently available to health care workers.

According to the Delaware Healthcare Association, there are a total of 395 intensive care unit beds at Delaware hospitals. A spokeswoman for the organization said it is "not possible to quantify exact numbers regarding our respiratory support equipment."

Health officials have said the state is talking to hospitals and the Delaware Emergency Management Agency every day and is monitoring the number of masks, test kits and other protective gear available.

Hospitals, including some here in Delaware, have been asking for donations.

“Right now, we have what we need in-state," Rattay said. "But we do have concerns that some of the items have certainly become more difficult to order.”

Gov. John Carney has said hospital capacity has been one of his biggest areas of concern.

During a March 19 interview with Delaware Online/The News Journal, Carney said he had received a spreadsheet that day that outlined what the hospitals have. He declined to make that information public.

"We don't have a lot in terms of a surge capacity," Carney said. "That's the biggest fear."

He said this has been a focus of the emergency management agency and there have been ongoing conversations with the National Guard, specifically about the potential of setting up a facility to handle a surge of cases.

One potential location, he said, is the building that used to house Milford Memorial Hospital.

What do experts say?

Since the first case was confirmed, The News Journal has received dozens of emails, phone calls and Facebook comments, all asking for more information about where the virus is in Delaware.

"How about the number actually tested," suggested Milford resident Lezlie Eustis, "broken down by age in decades, how many have other underlying health issues, how many live at home, and how many live at a care facility?"

"Are there clusters of cases in specific portions of the state?" asked Rehoboth Beach resident Glen Pruitt. He would also like to see a map identifying the towns where people with COVID-19 reside.

Dr. Mohammad Akhter, who also oversaw the Missouri and Washington, D.C., health departments, said he believes there is value in providing community-specific information.

If people knew there were confirmed cases in their town, or ZIP code, they would likely become more alert and take the precautions — such as social distancing — to protect themselves, the Delaware resident said.

"You cannot fight an infectious disease without being transparent. Eventually, the information will come out," Akhter said. “There is no infectious disease a health department can win without the help of the people.”

READ:Are Sussex County retirees and tourism prepared to weather Delaware's coronavirus crisis?

But due to the United States' privacy laws and Delaware’s small population size, this cannot be done in practice, said Jennifer Horney, the founding director of the University of Delaware’s epidemiology program.

“The law and guiding principle is to protect confidentiality,” she said. “This is the problem with small numbers.”

If for example, Horney said, the state released COVID-19 related information about a white 87-year-old woman from a small Delaware town, it wouldn’t take long for people to figure out who this resident is.

But this isn't good enough for Kowalko, a state representative, who has been frustrated with the information provided by the state.

While he said he believes Carney and health secretary Dr. Kara Odom Walker have done a good job addressing the outbreak, he also said Delawareans have a right to know what areas are being hit the worst by this pandemic.

"I think quite frankly the transparency has been horribly lacking," Kowalko said. "I say that to not criticize efforts that are made. I know HIPAA laws are well intended, but ... it's not to be a blanket."

search_result.title: Death and dying in Delaware
search_result.text:
Delaware Voice Joseph Carsello

It is rather significant that I am addressing the issue of death and dying since this is Holy Week.

A time when we commemorate the passion, death, burial and resurrection of Christ. During the past few months, the Delaware Health Care Commission's End-of-Life Work group has been conducting meetings throughout the state to receive input from professionals in the health care system, as well as the public, concerning the issues that are important when discussing end-of-life decisions.

Rep. Paul Baumbach has introduced a bill (the Death with Dignity Act, HB 150) which outlines the purposes and safeguards of the act. Now, there may be some people who say assisted suicide is an act that defies both moral and religious principles. I say that this is a human right given to us by God, since he has also given us a "free will" to decide whether a particular thought or action is inherently good or bad. It is only right that a competent person who has terrible physical pain and suffering, and has less than six months to live, be able to make his/her decision to end their life. If any of you have witnessed the dying and death of someone who has cancer, or the complications from AIDS, you understand what I am talking about. My sister died from lung cancer, and I witnessed the dying and deaths of many who died from AIDS complications when I was the executive director of Damien Ministries, and the Washington AIDS Ministry in Washington, D.C.

Besides the issues of death and dying covered in the act, I feel there are two other issues which are tangential to them. They were issues I discussed in a past letter to the editor concerning dying alone and being buried alone. As I stated in that letter to the editor, there are patients dying alone everyday in Delaware in hospitals, hospices, hospitals and nursing homes. Even Christ had his mother, and his mother's sister, Mary the wife of Clopas, Mary Magdalene, and his beloved disciple John, to witness his death.

The other issue related to dying and death with dignity in Delaware, relates to being buried alone with no one to be a witness to that person's life and death. All you have to do is glimpse at the obituaries in the Delaware News Journal, where there are not only obituaries, but also burial notices from funeral homes asking whether or not there were friends or relatives to claim the remains. In many cases, no one comes forward and they are buried alone. What is disturbing, is that there are the burial notices over the last month or two related to the remains of two babies that have no birth date or name.

What kind of society have we become that we do not even acknowledge the death and burial of babies?

Even Joseph of Arimathea, a disciple a Jesus, asked Pontius Pilate for the remains of Jesus. No one deserves to die or be buried alone in Delaware.

I wholeheartedly support Rep. Paul Baumbach's Death with Dignity Act, and I will work closely with the national organization and establish a Compassion and Choices chapter in Delaware. In addition, I will be forming a foundation in Delaware whose mission will be to make sure that Delawareans don't die alone, with volunteers that will be ready to assist in that effort by devoting their time and energy to be with those who need this service, and will be in constant contact with hospitals, hospices, and nursing homes to make sure that we provide the care giving for these abandoned individuals.

In addition, the Delaware Foundation for Equality in Death and Dying will be in contact with funeral homes to offer our services to those deceased with no one to claim their remains, so that we can claim their remains and provide a decent funeral or celebration of life. I urge you to call Rep. Baumbach and tell him you support his bill, as well as your state senator and state representative. The governor of Delaware (who already supports the bill) would like to hear from you too.

Joseph Carsello is the former executive director of Damien Ministries and the Washington AIDS Ministry in Washington. D.C. He is presently a volunteer with Delaware Hospice and AIDS Delaware and is a student of mortuary science.
