search_result.title: Delaware Democrats seek health coverage for children of immigrants
search_result.text:
A few thousand children are falling through the cracks of Delaware's health care system because of their immigration status, according to lawmakers determined to find a solution.

Democrats have introduced a bill to give health coverage to children in Delaware whose families have immigrated to the U.S. illegally.

Bill sponsors expect the bill to cover roughly 2,500 to 5,000 children. It's not clear exactly how many children would be covered by the bill because families are often fearful of coming forward, according to Rep. Krista Griffith, a Democrat from Fairfax who is sponsoring the bill.

As it stands now, the only coverage that the state and the federal government can provide is life-or-death emergency care, Griffith said.

Under the proposed legislation, children would be eligible for health coverage if they live in the state and their family income is low enough that they would qualify for Medicaid or the Children's Health Insurance Program coverage.

The bill is expected to affect only children who don't currently qualify for coverage because of their immigration status.

The Department of Health and Social Services would run the program, which would go into effect in January 2023 if the bill passes. Hospital, medical, dental and prescription drug benefits would align with Medicaid and CHIP coverage, according to the bill.

But the one-page bill could face obstacles from Gov. John Carney's administration, whose health secretary is hesitant about how the state will pay for it. It's expected to cost several million dollars per year.

Carney has not commented publicly on the bill but is typically hesitant about any proposals that include a recurring cost such as this one.

The 62-person, Democratic-controlled General Assembly has become increasingly progressive and willing to spend money on similar programs. But Carney, who has traditionally gotten his way in the Statehouse, is by comparison fiscally conservative.

"For thousands of Delaware children ... a simple trip to the doctor for an illness or to get vaccinated is not a financially viable option," Griffith said.

Sen. Sarah McBride, a Wilmington Democrat who is helping sponsor the bill, said the proposal is "financially responsible" because the current system is "inefficient." By expanding coverage, health outcomes will be improved and overall care costs for the state will go down in the long run, she said.

"None of them chose the broken immigration system that prevents them from seeing a pediatrician, and none of them chose to endure the kind of basic health concerns that afflict so many young people," McBride said.

Children getting poor treatment under current laws

Two parents who immigrated to Delaware shared examples of their families' health care challenges when the bill was introduced last week.

One mother, who did not give her name, said through a translator that her 14-year-old has no medical insurance and cannot get a checkup. Routine dentist appointments are too expensive, and she's limited to only doing the exams mandated by her child's school, she said.

Once, she took her child to the doctor for a skin problem. She was able to pay for the appointment, but when she went to the pharmacy to buy the medication he was prescribed, she couldn't afford it.

"One is there with one's heart torn apart," she said.

Another mother, who did not give her name, said she had trouble paying $300 for an ambulance to transport her child, at the time a 1-year-old, from the emergency room to the children's hospital for a respiratory condition.

Her daughter, who's older, has had fewer health problems. But recently, her teacher asked her family to take her to an ophthalmologist for vision problems. She's struggling to find care she can afford.

According to Dr. Marisel Santiago, a pediatrician at the La Red Health Center in Georgetown, pediatricians see "heartbreaking" situations when children don't qualify for health coverage because their family immigrated illegally. Parents struggle to pay for medication, tests and lab work. Some of the children they treat also have "terrible, terrible dental hygiene," she said.

She remembers one family who brought in their 8-year-old boy, who was severely obese. Doctors said they needed to do lab work on the child, but the family "just disappeared" because they couldn't afford it, she said.

Eventually, they came back and the child had lost weight despite eating the same and drinking more water. Doctors again ordered lab work, which the family again didn't do because they still couldn't afford it.

The child eventually ended up in the hospital with diabetic ketoacidosis, a life-threatening complication, and is now a type 1 diabetic patient, she said.

"The same way that we can provide school and education for every kid, no matter where they come from, we should be able to provide access to medical coverage," Santiago said.

PREGNANT WOMEN'S HEALTH CARE:Women's health care is a 'dire need' in Sussex County. And pregnant women, doctors know it

Progam not included in Carney's budget

The state will have to pay the full cost of the program, which would have to be written into next year's budget by the 12-person Joint Finance Committee that relies mostly on Carney's spending proposal when drafting.

Carney has not included this bill in his proposal, which he presented in January.

Besides McBride and Griffith, 25 other Democrats have signed on to the bill, which is essentially pledging their vote. But they will need more votes than that to pass it.

According to spending estimates from Nemours Children's Health and DHSS, it could cost the state between $3 million and $7 million per year, Griffith said.

Carney's office did not say whether or not the governor supports the bill.

"We'll be following legislative debate on the bill," said his spokesman, Jonathan Starkey.

"The real issue will come down to determining (the cost)," Griffith said.

Bill sponsors have pledged to work with the Carney administration on ways to fund it.

The bill won't be scheduled for a hearing until March, according to a House spokesperson.

The General Assembly is in session until the end of June. After that, they go on a six-month break.

The bill has support from Lt. Gov. Bethany Hall-Long and the Delaware State Education Association.

search_result.text:
The coronavirus pandemic has ended the 2020 Delaware high school basketball season.

After initially announcing a revised plan Thursday morning, the state high school athletic association canceled the state basketball tournament following the declaration of a state of emergency by Gov. John Carney later on Thursday.

No champion will be named, and the eight remaining boys and girls teams will receive Final Four trophies. The two Unified teams will be named co-champions.

The Delaware Interscholastic Athletic Association had earlier Thursday announced that the remaining games would be played with restricted attendance limited to legal guardians.

DIAA executive director Donna Polk said the tipping point was when Gov. Carney declared the state of emergency.

“It was a tough decision, but we have to do what’s in the best interest of our student-athletes and our community,” Polk said. “We have to follow the guidelines within the state, and once [Carney] indicated the state of emergency, looking at the guidelines we fell within that. We had to follow suit in regards to honoring that.”

HEIGHTENED ALERT:Governor declares state of emergency in Delaware after announcement of coronavirus cases

Polk was sympathetic to all the athletes involved, and all the coaches and athletic directors who had to inform them of the decision.

"The unknown is always scary,” St. Andrew's boys coach Terrell Myers said. “But you just want to make sure you’re taking all the precautions. Not only for the players, but for all of the families that are involved. When you put that as your No. 1 concern, then it makes a lot of sense. It puts sports as a secondary concern."

Sanford girls coach Marcus Thompson said the school's boys and girls basketball teams were practicing Thursday afternoon when athletic director Joan Samonisky brought them together and announced the cancellation.

“There were a lot of tears. This is tough,” Thompson said. “Not what anybody wanted.

“They’re heartbroken. Almost every girl on our team was crying, including the managers. This is something that they look forward to every year, the opportunity to be the best. This year, unfortunately they won’t get it.

“I’m in here trying to console guys and having conversations with a bunch of disappointed kids,” Sanford boys coach Stan Waterman said. “We have a lot of seniors, and it’s a really, really odd way for their high school careers to come to an end."

The alternate ending hadn't sunk in for Conrad Schools of Science senior Julie Kulesza, twice named Gatorade Player of the Year in Delaware.

“I know it’s going to hit me in the next couple of days; I’m just so shocked and in disbelief right now," she said.

“I feel really, really bad for the remaining girls of the four teams, and especially the seniors, that they got this far and couldn’t compete for a state championship,” said Dan Cooney, coach of the St. Elizabeth High School girls team. “But I also see where the state is coming from. They’ve got a big decision to make, and it’s not going to look popular in a lot of peoples’ eyes. But you’ve got to respect what they did.”

Delaware's first presumptive positive test, a faculty member at the University of Delaware, was announced Wednesday. Three more positive tests were reported Thursday, all also among people connected to the university, and the school paused its spring sports "until further notice."

Practices are under way for spring sports teams at high schools across the state, but Polk said DIAA is not involved in any decisions to cancel practices or preseason scrimmages.

“Those decisions will be made at the local level,” Polk said. “Superintendents and principals of the schools will be able to make those decisions.”

The DIAA seemed to be following in lockstep with Maryland, which announced a similar policy Wednesday night before announcing Thursday that its tournaments were postponed. In neighboring New Jersey, Thursday night state playoff games will be played without fans, but media will be allowed.

The situation escalated in a matter of days. DIAA first announced Tuesday night that the tournaments were being moved out of the University of Delaware's Bob Carpenter Center.

On Wednesday, new sites and times were officially announced.

THE LATEST: What you need to know about coronavirus in Delaware

The virus and the response to it surged beginning Wednesday night, the same day UD suspended classes.

In a matter of hours, president Donald Trump announced restrictions on overseas travel; an NBA player, Rudy Gobert, tested positive for the coronavirus; the league's season was immediately suspended; and the domino effect was on.

It continued Thursday, when the sports world came to a halt.

By midday, NCAA conference basketball tournaments were being canceled, and March Madness was off by the afternoon. There will be no spring NCAA championships, either.

The NHL, MLB and MLS announced suspension of their leagues.

In Philadelphia, the Sixers played a home game Wednesday night, and Thursday morning the Wells Fargo Center was closed for "extensive cleaning and sanitization."

FRANK: As coronavirus spreads, NBA does the right thing by suspending games. It was too late

Asked Thursday afternoon if this was all a distraction, Conrad girls coach John Kulesza recalled the team's 2018 run to a state championship, when snow had pushed the tournament back a few days. With the postponement, his No. 1 Conrad team was to practice Thursday and prepare to host a semifinal game Friday.

"We’ve always had the motto of 'Expect the unexpected,' " Kulesza said.

Hours later, those words rang true.

The News Journal's Jenna Miller contributed to this story.

search_result.title: Spring All-State High School Sports 2015
search_result.text:
The News Journal

The spring high school sports season saw its share of excitement, from Cape Henlopen winning its seventh straight girls lacrosse title to Appoquinimink winning the baseball crown for the school's first ever team state championship.

Behind those team achievements were great players. Let's take a look back at the most admirable student-athletes of the high school season.

Polytech girls lacrosse coach Lynn Richardson knew Ali McKay had the potential to score goals. That's why she moved McKay from defense to midfield before her sophomore season.

McKay was solid last year, earning second-team All-State honors. But this year, after some encouragement from her coach and teammates, she really turned it on. The junior led the Panthers with 104 goals, and was named the state's Player of the Year by the Delaware Girls Lacrosse Coaches Association.

"She's a well-rounded athlete, and she's a competitor, but I wouldn't say she is someone who is full of herself or overly confident," Richardson said. "We had to encourage her to shoot and drive to the goal."

Once the Panthers convinced her she could do it, the sky was the limit. READ MORE

GIRLS LACROSSE FIRST-TEAM ALL-STATE

Andrew Pettit had only one assist and no goals in his final high school lacrosse game.

But when it was over and Salesianum had secured a 12-2 victory in the semifinals of the DIAA Boys Lacrosse Tournament, the Tower Hill star was still the first topic of discussion for the Sals.

"We shut down Pettit," goalkeeper Ryan Kern said. "That was basically our whole game plan tonight, shut down Pettit."

Why would an opponent focus its entire defense on one man? Because Pettit finished his glittering career with school records for goals, assists and points, was a three-time first-team All-State selection and a two-time U.S. Lacrosse All-American. And this year, the Delaware Boys Lacrosse Coaches Association named Pettit the state's Player of the Year.

"What sets him apart are his stick skills and ability to create offense," Tower Hill coach Brad duPont said. "He has tremendous vision, and he knows where everybody is. He can put the ball on people's sticks."

He can put the ball in the net, too. And he can do it from any angle. READ MORE

BOYS LACROSSE FIRST-TEAM ALL-STATE

To hear Annie Jaskulski tell it, the most important tennis match of her high school career may well have been her first.

Strange when one considers she went unbeaten and won No. 1 singles state titles in each of her final three years at Wilmington Friends, including last month, the basis for a trio of Delaware High School Girls Tennis Player of the Year awards.

But that first match, as an eighth-grader playing first singles, set her priorities for her time at Friends and beyond.

"I lost my first match, against St. Andrew's," Jaskulski recalled during an interview at Bellevue Tennis Center. "I think it was 6-2, 6-3. It was the first time I was playing for a team. I was so disappointed; I didn't want to let my team down.

"I went home and told my parents that was the worst feeling ever and I didn't want to ever feel that again. I swore to myself I would never let my teammates down again." READ MORE

GIRLS TENNIS FIRST-TEAM ALL-STATE

Colt Williamson is on the road, a passenger in transit somewhere between Delaware and Maine. He listens on his cell phone, then redirects a question to his father.

"Do you have a claim to fame, Dad?" he says.

"Tell him you are" is the reply.

The subject is tennis, and for good reason. Williamson had just capped off his junior year at Milford High, having won the state boys singles championship. With his father, Rex, and "Pop Pop," Paul Williamson, coaching the team, Colt became the first Buccaneers No. 1 singles player to win a state title. Ever.

"That means a lot," Williamson said, " not just for me but for Milford finally having a state champ. Downstate, it's pretty much always been Caesar Rodney for as long as I've known. So, it's pretty nice to change it up a little bit and bring it to Milford." READ MORE

BOYS TENNIS FIRST-TEAM ALL-STATE

During a soccer game, Michelle Laz is like a shark.

Always in motion.

"I try to move around a lot," she said. "I don't stay stationary. If I see an open space, I quickly go there and call for the ball. Moving around is the best part of my game."

Laz found enough openings this spring to be named the state's Girls Soccer Player of the Year by the Delaware Soccer Coaches Association. The senior never stopped in leading Sussex Tech to a 13-4 season and a spot in the DIAA Division I semifinals.

Soccer is a long game, with a half lasting 40 minutes at the high-school level. Defenses threw everything but the kitchen sink at Laz, often shutting her down for long stretches. But more often than not, the end result was the same.

Late in the game, Laz would send a screamer into the back of the net, and the Ravens would celebrate a victory. READ MORE

GIRLS SOCCER FIRST XI

The high school golf season in Delaware can be boiled down to one event: The DIAA State Tournament.

All of the nine-hole matches held during the regular season fade into the background when the annual 36-hole test tees off at the end of the year. The golfer best able to handle the stress of the big occasion emerges as the champion.

For the second straight season, Salesianum's Liam Murphy passed the test with flying colors.

Last year, Murphy pulled away over the final nine holes at Dover's Maple Dale Country Club to win by four strokes. This year, the senior broke out of the pack again at Wilmington Country Club on May 26-27 to win by five and earn his second straight Golfer of the Year honor.

"There's really no better feeling than to be able to go in there and pull it off, and prove to yourself that you can do it," Murphy said. "All of those hours that you put in were worth it." READ MORE

ALL-STATE GOLF TEAM

In a sport whose defining adjectives are "faster," "higher" and "stronger," Ashley Bailey is all of the above.

Soaring 18 inches higher than any other Delaware girl ever before pole vaulted, excelling in five other events and leading her team to unprecedented success, the Middletown High senior won the Bill Thomson Award as the state's outstanding high school track athlete.

Just this past Sunday, Bailey vaulted 13 feet at the Junior Olympic Regionals at Stockton (N.J.) University, in a performance she would have undoubtedly reached during the high school season, but for the other work she had taken on.

Requiring speed, strength and jumping ability, the pole vault attracts the sport's most versatile athletes. But the compact schedule of a track meet prevents most vaulters from showing their skills in other events. Bailey, though, invariably performed in the maximum four events. READ MORE

ALL-STATE GIRLS TRACK & FIELD TEAM

If this decade has been a golden era for distance running, 2015 was platinum. Six of the top 12 milers in Delaware history competed this spring, five of them graduating last month.

In this elite field, Kieran Tuntivate dominated. The Harvard-bound senior broke the state records in the mile and 1,600 meters both indoors and out, became Delaware's third-fastest ever at 3,200 meters, set a school record in the 800 to clinch the Blue Hen Conference championship for Charter School of Wilmington and earned national notice at major invitational races.

In a year when Mykele Young-Sanders of Dover overcame mid-season injury to complete an unprecedented three-year sweep of the hurdles events and Jarod Wilson of Newark became Delaware's fastest half-miler in 30 years, Tuntivate earned the Tom Fort Award as the state's top male track athlete. READ MORE

ALL-STATE BOYS TRACK & FIELD TEAM

Regan Green's mother teases her, says her neck will get sore from watching the batters hit her pitches in college.

For four years, Green strained the necks of high school hitters as they watched her pitches scream past.

The Laurel right-hander left a trail of statistics and memorable performances that will become part of the lore of Delaware high school softball. A perfect game in a DIAA state final. Two state championships. A career ERA of 0.70, and a career average of 14.2 strikeouts per seven innings.

So even though the Bulldogs came up short in their bid for a three-peat, Green was a clear choice as The News Journal's Softball Player of the Year. The senior's contribution in the dugout was as important as her work in the pitcher's circle.

"I became a better leader on the team," she said. "You usually think of the pitcher as one of the leaders, but I had never really been in that spot because of the seniors that we've had. This year, I had to step up to it." READ MORE

ALL-STATE SOFTBALL TEAM

Brandon Walter allowed two earned runs in the first inning of Hodgson's season opener against eventual state champion Appoquinimink.

Then he allowed one more earned run – the rest of the season.

The 6-foot-2 left-hander put together one of the greatest seasons in the history of Delaware high school baseball, making him an obvious selection as the state's Player of the Year by the Delaware Baseball Coaches Association.

Walter's numbers bordered on the absurd. He struck out 147 in 72 innings, and allowed just 25 hits, 16 walks and three earned runs. The opposition flailed away to a .116 batting average.

"He was as dominant of a pitcher as I've ever seen, coached, been around," Hodgson coach Chris Moxley said.

He set a state record with six shutouts, threw a no-hitter April 2 against St. Georges and set another state mark with 19 strikeouts against A.I. du Pont on May 11. And he did it by consistently throwing the ball over the plate. READ MORE

search_result.title: Amish Outlaws talk loving rap music, religion, being shunned & more
search_result.text:
What happens when a hip-hop fan who was raised Amish decides to leave the church and start a popular band that occasionally tours to Delaware?

You end up with performers whose stage names sound like this: Snoop Job (Snoop Dog), Big Daddy Abel (Big Daddy Kane), Eazy Ezekiel (Eazy-E), Amos Def (Mos Def), Hezekiah X (Malcolm X).

The drummer is named "Jakob the Pipeplayer." His name isn't tied to any famous rappers or historic Black figures. But the alias sounded funky enough, so it stuck.

Those are the members in the cover band The Amish Outlaws, a group playing nearly a dozen shows in the First State heading into summer. Their next Delaware stop is a free show at Paradise Grill in Millsboro on Sunday, March 17, and there are three more through August.

The band also will play a free show at Dover Motor Speedway during NASCAR weekend in April. Their first time gigging at the Speedway was in 2022 when they opened for country star Jimmie Allen.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

Amish band plays 50 Cent

The band started in 2003 with four of six original members who grew up in strict Amish households in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, where there weren't any power lines connected to their homes. There also wasn't any alcohol or musical instruments.

While not everyone in the band's current lineup is Amish, all members perform in Amish attire. This means straw hats, suspenders, and light blue button-up shirts.

Ezekiel Scott, better known as band co-founder "Eazy Ezekiel," said The Amish Outlaws usually throw new audiences for a loop in concert.

Many people don't expect a band dressed so plainly to cover everything from System of a Down (metal) to 50 Cent (rap) and Luke Byran (country), one song after the other.

"When we get on stage and start to play, usually it's confusion for them ... then heads start to bob," Eazy, 49, of Stoney Point, New York, said.

Amish Outlaws: 'I loved NWA'

Eazy Ezekiel is responsible for his bandmate's rap-inspired stage names. He also named Elijah Rule (Ja Rule), a former member of the group.

Coming straight outta Lancaster, Eazy Ezekiel says the concept behind that was important.

"I loved N.W.A. I loved Eazy-E's 'Eazy-Duz-It' album," he said. "We didn't want to use our family names because we want to protect our family's privacy ... not that we expected [the band] to be as popular as it is."

Meet the Amish 'Mos Def' from Delaware

Amos Def (keyboardist) is the only member of The Amish Outlaws who lives in Delaware. He appreciates his stage name and the rapper who inspired it.

"I love a good punny name, but also Mos Def is one of my all-time favorite rappers, so I treat [my name] with great respect and deference," said Amos Def, who has lived in Pike Creek for two years. "I also love his movie with Jack Black, 'Be Kind Rewind.'"

Why did he leave the Amish church?

Some Amish communities practice a tradition called "Rumspringa" where when Amish children turn 16, they can live free of the strict Amish code of conduct before deciding if they want to come back and be baptized into the Amish church. The practice applies sometimes just to male youths.

Most of the youth return. Rumspringa doesn't have a deadline, but it typically lasts a year, Eazy said.

Ezekiel said he left the Amish church because he didn't like the idea that God would punish some of the friends he made during Rumspringa.

"I couldn't reconcile myself with the belief that because somebody just happened to not be raised or born Amish that he or she was gonna go to hell," he explained.

While he's no longer part of the Amish church, Eazy still considers himself Amish. He's just a non-practicing Amish. "It's still my heritage. That's the best way to phrase it."

A misconception about Amish shunning

There's a popular idea that the few people who leave the Amish community after Rumspringa are shunned for life. Eazy said that's not true because each sect is different.

The bassist explained he still has a good relationship with his parents, who live in Lancaster. His older brothers left the Amish church and have seen their little bro perform. But his parents have never attended any of Eazy's concerts, which are sometimes at bars.

"I mean, I understand. They're not supposed to go into a bar," he said about his Amish parents.

Discovering music by Pink Floyd & The Beatles

It was during Rumspringa when Ezekiel began exploring music.

"Music became, beyond my family, my biggest passion. It's just something I love more than just about anything in the world," he explained.

At the age of 18, he moved to New York and a friend introduced him to The Beatles' album "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" and Pink Floyd's "The Wall."

"Suddenly music went from a distraction or entertainment to something with a very deep, almost sub-religious meaning."

Delaware embraces Amish Outlaws

Ezekiel would go on to found The Amish Outlaws, a band that has been going strong for 21 years.

These days, Delaware is playing a bigger role in the band's success. At one point, it was a state the guys would drive through. From now through August, the band is playing the First State nearly a dozen times.

"Delaware has really become one of our absolute strongest and most receptive markets," Eazy said.

Amish Outlaws upcoming Delaware concerts

For more info about The Amish Outlaws, visit amishoutlaws.com. See below for their upcoming Delaware shows:

search_result.title: Amish Outlaws to perform in Yonkers
search_result.text:
Kevin Phelan

kphelan@lohud.com

Brother %22Eazy%22 Ezekiel of The Amish Outlaws discusses the Amish community and discovering music

%22I call it Amish Shock and Awe%2C%22 Eazy says of a typical Amish Outlaws show

%22As much as I love playing music%2C I love listening to it even more%2C%22 Eazy says

The band will play a free show on June 25 to kick of Cross County Shopping Center%27s Summer Fest

It's a safe bet you've never seen an act quite like The Amish Outlaws before.

"I call it Amish Shock and Awe," says Brother "Eazy" Ezekiel, one of the band's founding members, vocalists and its bassist. "Not just the garb, but seeing six of us up there going from Elvis to Snoop Dogg to Billy Idol to Johnny Cash to Lady Gaga in a 15-minute period usually has folks kind of surprised."

The band, comprised of 3 former Amish and 3 "Honorary Amish" members, cover songs from a variety of genres while dressed in the religion's traditional apparel — hats, suspenders and all.

Eazy was raised in an Amish community in Lancaster, Pa., until, at age 16, he went on Rumspringa, an Amish rite of passage. "It means 'running around,' in the literal translation," he explains. "The Amish don't baptize their children, you make the choice as an adult to be baptized and before you do, you go out and experience the world free of the rules of the Amish beliefs and decide if you want to go back and join Church or not."

He continued to live at home until 18, but Eazy never returned to the Amish lifestyle, saying, "I couldn't go back and shut off the outside world once I had really tapped into it."

The Amish Outlaws will play a free concert Wednesday, kickingoff Cross County Shopping Center's Summer Fest, a three-month celebration of the center's 60th anniversary, which includes free concerts, fireworks, a sidewalk chalk art festival, kids' activities and more.

Eazy answered a few questions about leaving the community, discovering music and whether there really is an Amish Mafia.

How much exposure to music did you have growing up in the Amish community?

Very little. There was singing from the Ausbund, a song book of religious songs, which was beautiful in its way, but very simple. I heard bits and pieces of modern music out in the world, at a store or a business or coming from a passing car. As kids we would sneak around and hear music outside and inside some places where we knew it would be playing, but I never listened to any music regularly until I left.

What made you decide not to return?

Reading and music. I couldn't give either up. I got my GED and wound up going to college and studying, among other things, literature, and couldn't unlearn all that I did and close my eyes to it and go back and live Amish. There is nothing wrong with living Amish, I am not implying that by any stretch. It may sound like I am trying to say to live Amish is to live in ignorance. Far from it.

How did your family react?

Luckily an older brother made the decision before me and kind of broke the ice, so I got off a lot easier than he did, but they weren't happy at first. A lot of guilt trips and hawing, but from a place of love. I still get it occasionally. I am sure they still aren't happy about it, but after this long, acceptance has set in.

Have any of them been to your shows?

My older brother has, but not other family.

How difficult was transitioning from the Amish community to the outside world?

It was a gradual process for me; going out into the world and experiencing it while still living at home, then in an apartment. Moving to New York was a shock. I am not in the city, but I have been there a lot. The hardest part, though, is the lack of quiet ... the cacophony of phones and cars and machines and blips is hard to shut out sometimes. Missing my family was the only thing more difficult.

When did you know you wanted to pursue music?

It was during the first year of my Rumspringa when an English friend played Pink Floyd's "The Wall" and "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" by The Beatles. He had them on vinyl — his father's copies, with the inserts and lyrics — and it wasn't until I held those albums and heard them and read the words that I realized music can mean so much. As much as I love playing music, I love listening to it even more.

How do you feel about the Amish-centric shows that are cropping up on TV?

We get asked about them non-stop; 'Is the Amish Mafia real?' My answer is usually, 'If a bunch of people were doing illegal stuff on TV, wouldn't the police come and arrest them?' There is a reason they digitize people's faces on "Cops"… I have seen about five minutes each of "Breaking Amish" and "Amish Mafia" and of course I don't know the people on that show so I can't say how or who they really are, but it seems to me like people acting the way they think people should act on TV, but in bonnets and suspenders.

If you go

What: The Amish Outlaws

Where: Cross County Shopping Center, 8000 Mall Walk, Yonkers. 914-968-9570. Crosscountycenter.com.

When: 7-9 p.m. Wednesday

More: Concert is free, but guests are encouraged to bring beach chairs or blankets. Visit Amishoutlaws.com for additional shows.

Spring is around the corner, which means Delaware's seasonal beach bars will start opening for 2019.

Here's some of what to expect.

The Starboard

The Dewey Beach venue on 2009 Coastal Highway, a known St. Patrick's Day weekend destination, will celebrate this season's opening weekend on March 14-17.

The Amish Outlaws, an Amish cover band, will perform on opening night at 8 p.m., according to the event's Facebook page.

The musical duo Kristen and Johnny will play at The Starboard on Saturday, according to the venue's Facebook page. The band La Unica, followed by musician Bryen O'Boyle, will perform on St. Patrick's Day on Sunday, according to its Facebook page.

Mango's

The Caribbean restaurant in Bethany Beach, home of the "Mangorita," will celebrate this season's opening weekend starting March 29 at 97 Garfield Parkway.

The official opening party is March 30. The band Electric Velvet will play at the party, according to the venue's Facebook post. Happy hour is from 1-6 p.m.

Nalu

The Hawaiian surf bar and grill's Dewey Beach location at 1308 Coastal Highway is open for the season.

Springtime hours are Thursdays and Fridays from 4 p.m. to 1 a.m.; and Saturdays and Sundays from 11:30 a.m. to 1 a.m. The location will be open daily starting in May.

Nalu's new Rehoboth Beach location is slated to open April 9.

The new venue on 41 Rehoboth Ave. is hiring for the 2019 season, according to its Facebook post. Interviews will be at its Dewey Beach location on March 14 from 5-8 p.m., the post said.

Big Chill Beach Club

Not to be confused with the Rehoboth venue of the same name, this Bethany Beach restaurant and bar's opening weekend for the 2019 season is April 26-28.

The restaurant on 27099 Coastal Highway is known for its roof deck and umbrella bar.

"The sunsets are waiting & we can't wait to see everyone this 2019 season!" the Facebook event page reads. "Be sure to invite your friends & family for another great season."

Roger Hillis

Special to Salisbury Daily Times

The Cowboy Coast Saloon in Ocean City hosted a plethora of country, rock and pop concerts this past summer, but it saved its biggest music event of the year for the off-season.

Hip-hop icon Method Man, who is both a solo artist and a member of the Wu Tang Clan, will appear at 9 p.m. on Saturday, Dec. 7. Early-bird $30 ticket sales have ended. General admission tickets are now $40, while “expedited admission” tickets will allow patrons to cut in line for $80. Big spenders can spring for a VIP table for a whopping $1,000.

Method Man is celebrating the 25th anniversary of his “Tical” album, and has released a new video for the song “Squad Up.”

Elsewhere in OC, Seacrets will host its third annual Holiday Bazaar & Bubbly event at 6 p.m. Friday, Dec. 6 ($20). Full Circle will perform as an acoustic duo, as area boutiques showcase art, holiday decor and more.

Next week the nightspot will host its free Ocean 98 Listener & Seacrets Customer Appreciation Christmas Party from 5-10 p.m. Friday, Dec. 13. Music will be provided by Lower Case Blues, Full Circle, Jocelyn & Christ Arndt, Brandon Hardesty and Howi Spangler.

In downtown Rehoboth Beach, the Dogfish Head brewpub will present a free concert by Philadelphia indie music act Work Drugs at 10 p.m. Friday, Dec. 6. The synth-pop duo, comprised of Thomas Crystal and Benjamin Louisiana, is often joined on stage by auxiliary players. It is promoting its third album, “Fantasty File.”

The Milton Theatre will host two concerts in one day by an Everly Brothers tribute act on Sunday, Dec. 8. The Zmed brothers will stage their Everly Brothers Experience Holiday Show at 3 p.m, and also 8 p.m., with tickets for each priced at $27 and $32.

Back in Ocean City, B.J.’s On the Water will host its annual Christmas party at 6 p.m. Wednesday, Dec. 12. Admission is free, and classic rock tunes will be delivered live courtesy the restaurant’s house band, Teenage Rust & the Rustettes.

search_result.title: Franklin County, Pa., carnivals and fairs 2021: When are they?
search_result.text:
Carnivals and fairs are finally returning to Franklin County starting this week.

Just like everything else fun, they were canceled last year due to the pandemic.

There will be plenty of opportunities to make up for those lost summer memories over the next several weeks. Check out this list of carnivals and fairs in and near Franklin County.

Fayetteville Firemen's Carnival

Enjoy bingo, rides, games, food trucks and live entertainment. The fire company's food stand will offer its "famous" homemade chicken corn soup and ham and bean soup. Don't miss the fireworks on June 12 (rain date on June 11).

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

When: Thursday, June 3 through Saturday, June 12. Gates open at 5 p.m.

Where: Fayetteville Volunteer Fire Department's carnival grounds, 101 W. Main St., Fayetteville

Cost: Parking and admission are free. Bring money for rides, games and food.

Live music: Bands take the stage at 7 p.m. each night. Here's the schedule: June 3: Guilford Station; June 4: Hubcaps; June 5: Mustang Sally; June 6: Make Mine Country; June 7: The Amish Outlaws; June 8: Sandalwood; June 9: Cash Unchained; June 10: Regan Year; June 11: Chris Woodward; June 12: Revolution.

More info: Check out the fire department's Facebook page for updates.

Things to do:Looking for things to do in the Cumberland Valley? Here are our best bets for June

The Marion Festivals

Rides, games, bingo and entertainment are featured each Saturday evening in June in this little town between Greencastle and Chambersburg. Food trucks and Marion Volunteer Fire Company's food stand will be open.

Proceeds from this event pay for the street lights in Marion and help the Marion Athletic Association and the fire department.

When: June 5, 12, 19 and 26. The kitchen opens at 4:30 p.m. each day.

Where: Marion Festival Grounds, 82 Kennedy St., Marion

Cost: No charge to park, but bring money for rides, games and food

Live music: Each festival will have three free shows (6:15, 7:30 and 9 p.m.) by a live band. Here's the schedule: June 5: Brush Fire Band; June 12: No Limit; June 19: Bobby D & the Truck Stop Burritos; June 26: Make Mine Country.

More info: http://www.mv8fc.com/

Mont Alto Fireman's Carnival

Nine nights of carnival rides, food, 25-cent bingo, small games for cash and prizes, and live music. Don't miss the fireworks on June 18 (rain date, June 19)

When: Friday, June 11 through Saturday, June 19. The kitchen opens at 5:30 p.m.

Where: Mont Alto Fire Company Event Complex, 603 E. Main St., Mont Alto

Cost: Bring money for rides, games and food. The kitchen will accept major credit cards.

Live music: June 11: Luke Lucas; June 12: Countdown Band; June 13: Fabulous Hubcaps; June 14: Chris Woodward and Shindiggin; June 15: Reagan Years; June 16: Amish Outlaws; June 17: Michael Christopher Band; June 18: Dean Crawford, Dunns River Band; June 19: Out of Line

More info: http://www.montaltofire.com/events/fireman-s-carnival

Franklin County Fair

If your family needs a break from the Ferris wheels, Zippers, Scramblers and other traditional carnival rides, go to this county fair for something a little different. The midway is home to a variety of bounce houses, obstacle courses, a rock-climbing wall and other attractions.

It is a county fair, so the schedule is full of livestock shows, truck and tractor pulls and various contests. Kids can even compete in the Barnyard Olympics or the coloring contest.

When: Sunday, July 11 through Saturday, July 17. Monday through Saturday, the grounds and food stands will be open 10 a.m. to 10 p.m., although some livestock events begin at 9. The bounce houses and other attractions open at 6 p.m. Monday-Friday and at noon on Saturday. Only the food stands (5 p.m.) and the annual vesper service (6 p.m.) will take place on Sunday.

Where: Chambersburg Rod and Gun Club, 3725 Warm Spring Road, Chambersburg

Cost: Admission is free, but parking is $5 per vehicle 4-9 p.m. Monday-Thursday and 3-9 p.m. Friday and Saturday.

Event highlights:

Franklin County Fair Royalty contests: Girls and teens compete on Monday evening for the opportunity to represent the county fair and local agriculture for the next year. Little Miss pageant, 6 p.m.; Princess pageant, 7 p.m.; Queen pageant, 8 p.m.

Barnyard Olympics, Saturday: Kids ages 3 and older compete (by age classes) in "home spun games" including bale throw, sack race, egg toss and an obstacle course. The event is at 10 a.m. Saturday on the Midway Stage. Register starting one hour before, same place.

Live music: Musical acts will perform on the Midway Stage -- Elvis the Tribute by David King, 7:30 p.m. Tuesday; Keystone State Quartet (Southern gospel), 7 and 8:30 p.m. Wednesday; Rock 'n Roll Relics, 7:30 and 9; New Country (traditional country), 7 and 9 p.m.

Baby Barnyard: Who doesn't want to meet little piglets, calves, chicks, billies, lambs and other baby furry friends? There are even some animals this year - even hatching chicks - as well as ag education stations and a kids' corner with face painting, coloring, storytime and crafts. This attraction is open every day of the fair, all day (except for Saturday when it opens at noon), under the tent on the midway. In addition, there will be an educational talk about a different farm animal each weekday at 6 p.m.

Arena events: The arena will be a busy place during fair week as the home of the popular Interstate Truck and Tractor Pull (7 p.m. Monday and 6:30 p.m. Friday), Skid Loader Rodeo (7 p.m. Tuesday), Antique Tractor Pull (6 p.m. Wednesday), and Garden Tractor Pull (7 p.m. Thursday). Bullride Mania, at 7:30 p.m. Saturday, will also take place there.

Full schedule and other details: https://www.franklincountyfair.org/

Post-COVID summer:Franklin County residents make summer plans, post-vaccines: vacations, family gatherings

Shippensburg Community Fair

Thousands of people visit this staple of the Shippensburg community every year. There are 35 rides by Pennwood Amusements and more than 20 food stands hosted by local nonprofit organizations, and the schedule is full of livestock shows and contests and other agriculture events.

When: Monday, July 26 to Saturday, July 31. The fair is officially open 4-11 p.m. every day, but it opens early at 10:30 a.m. for Kiddie Day on Wednesday and Saturday. Some food vendors are open for lunch. A Shippensburg Band concert and community vespers service will take place July 25 on the fair stage.

Where: Shippensburg Community Fairgrounds, 10131 Possum Hollow Road, Shippensburg

Cost: Admission is free, but parking is $5 per vehicle. Weekly parking passes are $15. For rides during regular fair hours, tickets are $1 apiece (or $30 for 40) and wristbands for unlimited rides are $25.

Event highlights:

Kiddie Day: Held 10:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. Wednesday and Saturday, this is the time to bring the kids to the Shippensburg Fair. All rides are discounted to one ticket, and wristbands are just $15. The ticket stands close at 3:30.

Fair food: One day at the fair is not enough to get a taste of what the food stands have to offer. Check out the menu at the fair website, shippensburgfair.squarespace.com.

Fair Royalty Pageants: Girls and teens will compete Monday evening on the fair stage for the opportunity to represent the fair and agriculturism in the Shippensburg area. Queen pageant, 7:30 p.m.; Little Miss pageant, 6 p.m.

Live music: Four live bands will perform free shows at 7:30 p.m. -- The Chris Ruble Band (country/classic rock), Tuesday; Into the Spin (pop, rock, soul), Wednesday; Presley and Taylor (country duet), Thursday; The Hobbs Sisters (modern country), Saturday.

Full schedule and other details: https://shippensburgfair.squarespace.com/

Bonus: Fulton County Fair

Take a trip west on U.S. 30 over the mountain for a good time at this fair, which is celebrating its 100th year in 2021.

When: Sunday, Aug. 1 through Saturday, Aug. 7. Rides open at 5 p.m. on Monday and Wednesday-Saturday and 2 p.m. on Tuesday.

Where: 888 Lincoln Way East, McConnellsburg

Cost: Admission is $9 including rides and $6 without rides; kids 2 and under free, rides not included.

Full schedule and other details: http://www.fultoncountypafair.com

Amber South can be reached at asouth@publicopinionnews.com.

search_result.title: Taxes increased to fund jetty repair at Sebastian Inlet State Park
search_result.text:
INDIAN RIVER COUNTY — The Sebastian Inlet District has increased its tax rate 45% and more than doubled its budget for the coming year in order to begin work on two major projects.

The 2024-2025 tax rate — which went into effect with the new budget year Oct. 1 — is .16 mills, up from .11 mills. The district's budget for 2024-2025 is nearly $22 million, up 103% the 2023-2024 budget, which was almost $11 million.

The Sebastian Inlet District is charged with maintaining the inlet and keeping it open for shipping, tourism, recreation and navigation.

“Sebastian Inlet District increased its millage rate to fund a north jetty maintenance project — which has been previously deferred — and the scheduled sand trap dredging and beach renourishment projects,” said Sebastian Inlet District Chairman Jenny Lawton Seal.

The north jetty, a popular fishing spot, is on the Brevard County side of the inlet, and needs routine maintenance due to weathering, such as wood support-beam replacement and rock replacement at the foundation. The north jetty protects the inlet from sand filling in and closing the passage.

Sand trap dredging removes sand from the inlet, putting it along beaches to replace sand lost to erosion.

More:Indian River County adds 37 employees, increases sheriff's budget for upcoming fiscal year

More:Vero Beach maintains tax rate, gives raises, but property taxes still could be going up

Sebastian Inlet State Park is located on both sides of the inlet. It contains both the McLarty Treasure Museum and Sebastian Fishing Museum, and is world-renowned for surfing.

Nick Slater is TCPalm's Indian River County Watchdog reporter. You can reach him at Nick.Slater@tcpalm.com and 224-830-2875.

The Brevard County Commission will decide on Tuesday how to resolve controversies involving tourism grants for cultural organizations and events, as well as for projects to help improve the condition of the Indian River Lagoon. Also in the mix: How to adequately fund post-hurricane repairs to beach areas in south Brevard.

The advisory Brevard County Tourist Development Council has recommended a plan that would fully fund all of that through the 5% tourist development tax on hotel rooms and other short-term rentals.

Under the TDC's proposal, commissioners would agree to use money built up in the cultural fund to fund the $1 million-a-year Tourism + Indian River Lagoon Grant Program in the 2023-24 budget year that begins Oct. 1. Then, the Office of Tourism would use new tourist tax revenue to pay for cultural grants that would be awarded for 2023-24.

County commissioners on March 7 had discussed ― but did not vote on ― an earlier council recommendation to suspend lagoon grant funding for one year so that more money could go toward beach restoration. Commissioners didn't like that idea, and instead sent the issue back to the TDC, asking for a recommendation that would include funding for the lagoon grant program.

Funding shift proposed:New proposal: Take tourism cultural grant money and shift it to lagoon, beach projects

Currently, 25% of the revenue from the tourist development tax goes toward a fund used for beach renourishment and the lagoon grant program. And 4% goes to the cultural fund that is used for cultural grants; for major events grants like air shows and the Thunder on Cocoa Beach powerboat races; and to partially funding the Brevard Cultural Alliance. The largest share of the tourist tax revenue — 47% — goes toward a comprehensive plan to market the Space Coast as a destination for tourists.

The County Commission has the power to change those allocations.

Some tourism council members feared that any temporary cuts to the cultural grants program would become permanent.

Spring break frenzy:Record-setting Space Coast spring break has Cocoa Beach area buzzing

In the current budget year, 22 arts and cultural organizations and events received tourism cultural grants totaling $340,000. In addition, Thunder on Cocoa Beach received a major events grant of $49,996.

The Tourism + Indian River Lagoon Grant Program funded a range of projects this year, includes ones dealing with seagrass restoration, improving the clam and oyster populations in the lagoon, and removal of derelict boats from waterways.

Hurricanes Ian and Nicole caused $22.49 million in damage to Brevard's south beaches area, which is a 14.5-mile stretch from Spessard Holland Park south to Sebastian Inlet. Repairs to the beaches will use all current beach funds, plus require an additional $6.44 million to be drawn from federal American Rescue Plan Act funds the county received. County commissioners approved that ARPA allocation on Dec. 6,.

The south beaches project is eligible for reimbursement from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. But FEMA reimbursements typically occur about three years after a storm. So until FEMA reimbursement is received, if another storm damages the beaches during the 2023 hurricane season, the beach fund are depleted.

The TDC also approved these recommendation, which will come up for discussion at Tuesday's County Commissions meeting:

Voted 9-0 to recommend not diverting further money from the beach fund for uses other than beach renourishment until that fund is once again solvent.

Voted 9-0 to recommend increasing the maximum available grants for cultural organizations to $15,000 for those that attract 1,000 to 2,500 out-of-county attendees; $20,000 for those that attract 2,501 to 5,000 out-of-county attendees; and 25,000 for those that attract more than 5,000 out-of-county attendees. The current maximum grants are $10,000, $15,000 and $20,000, respectively.

Voted 7-2 to continue to allow municipalities to be eligible for cultural grants, overriding an earlier recommendation of the TDC's Cultural Committee that municipalities should no longer be eligible for such grants. TDC Chair Rita Pritchett, who also chairs the County Commission, and Cultural Committee Chair Andrea Young, who is a member of the West Melbourne City Council, voted no. TDC member Rob Medina, who is mayor of Palm Bay, pushed for municipalities to continue to be eligible for such grants. Palm Bay was a cultural grant recipient for the current budget year.

search_result.title: Beach replenishment changing Delaware shoreline
search_result.text:
Molly Murray

The News Journal

When Hurricane Sandy made landfall just north of Atlantic City three years ago, it swept away homes, beaches and dunes.

But the storm left another legacy: a shift in the approach state, federal and local regulators take to make shorelines storm ready and resilient.

From New England to the Carolinas, dredges have pumped millions of cubic yards of sand, in the three years since Sandy struck, to build storm-ready beaches and form engineered sand dunes. The trend is coast-long, even in places where the strategy had been to allow nature to take its course.

Delaware alone received $30 million in federal Sandy relief money to restore sand that was swept away during the hurricane in 2012. Another $38 million is being spent at Prime Hook National Wildlife Refuge to restore wetlands and fill shoreline breaches that Sandy worsened.

The sand pumping there – in an area that federal officials had allowed to retreat as sand washed over into the adjacent marsh during storms – started last week.

But this new policy could be short-lived, said Howard Marlowe, with Warwick Group Consultants, a Washington-based consulting firm. Marlowe is an expert on beach rehabilitation funding, having lobbied on behalf of communities for several years. He has shifted his focus to a regional approach to shoreline management and to finding new sources of sand such as reuse of dredge spoils.

His predicts that when it comes time for maintenance and repairs of all these created beaches, there won't be enough federal money to go around.

"They'll be bumping into each other," he said of state and local governments who will be jockeying for a share of federal money. "There's going to be a load of beaches between 2017 and 2020" that will need maintenance and repairs – and that's without a significant storm or hurricane. "There's going to be a significant lack of money if I had to bet on it."

That puts Delaware communities like Bethany and South Bethany – where as much of one-third of the protective sand dune was chopped off during a long-duration coastal storm earlier in October – in a predicament. The two communities are in line for federal maintenance sand pumping in 2017.

Anthony P. Pratt, the state shoreline and waterway manager, said he isn't worried about availability of federal money for the Delaware projects. In each case, there is a 50-year contract for continued U.S. Army Corps of Engineers maintenance.

"It really hasn't changed our world, at all," he said. All the projects that were initiated after Sandy were pre-approved, Pratt said.

Marlowe has witnessed the struggle over money for beaches. He said it dates back to the Clinton administration, and the start of funding cuts for federal dollars for beach rehabilitation. Back then, there were fewer beaches in line for money. Among them: several in New Jersey, Florida and Ocean City, Maryland. These days – after emergency projects following Sandy – that funding pot may not be large enough to cover all the future repair needs.

The root of the problem, Marlowe said, is there isn't a federal coastal policy on beach renourishment. So while federal flood insurance may give people an incentive to build higher or farther from the sea, exactly where and how people build is controlled by local rules.

He believes states should work together on a regional basis to prioritize shoreline repair needs, reduce the cost of mobilizing dredge crews ( that mobilization cost can be significant) and work with federal agencies to find and use sand being removed as part of other projects.

Pratt said that before Sandy, officials in Delaware, Maryland, New York and New Jersey had started to work together but the effort was put on hold after the hurricane.

The idea, he said, was to find ways to make beach repairs more efficient by combining contracts to reduce overall costs.

Fowler Beach Fix

At Fowler Beach, there is a one-time effort to build a more storm resilient wetland and shoreline. Even before Sandy, lower Delaware Bay residents begged federal officials to fill the breaches along the bay shoreline.

"At first, it was a battle," said Jim Bailey, president of the Broadkill Beach Preservation Association, of the push by area residents, farmers and landowners to get federal officials to address the problem. "Now it's a cooperative effort."

Three years after Sandy, the Fowler Beach sand pumping project is the largest of the Delaware shoreline repair projects. The plan is to pump 1.1 million cubic yards of sand to fill a series of breaches and inlets blamed for flooding in nearby communities, killing trees in adjacent woods and flooding nearby farm fields with salt water. The repeated inundation prompted farmers to build earthen berms to keep the flood waters out.

Last week, a survey boat made a final series of calculations and then a plug in the pipeline was removed. The pipe was primed with seawater and then, on Oct. 21, the first of the sand that will be pumped onto Fowler Beach, spilled through the pipeline. The area is southeast of Milford and is currently inaccessible. The road is closed while the dredging work is underway. Eventually, federal refuge officials may install a footpath into the restored area.

"In the beginning, it was a battle," said Jim Bailey, president of the Broadkill Beach Preservation Association, of the push by area residents, farmers and landowners to get federal officials to address the problem. "Now it's a cooperative effort."

The plan, said Bart Wilson, the project manager for the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service Prime Hook National Wildlife Refuge, is to work north first and then shift to the south to fill the largest in a series of breaches between Fowler and Prime Hook beaches.

While the Fowler Beach breach opened during previous storms – the first was in 2008 – it was worsened during Sandy. Today, it is more an inlet than a breach, sending water into and out of the marsh with every high and low tide on Delaware Bay.

"We have the Prime Hook Sound," now, Bailey said.

Once the breach formed, water flooded a manmade water holding structure originally designed to draw in ducks and geese during migration each fall. The area became a rich habitat for ducks that favored fresh and brackish water.

But once the shoreline was breached, the old structure flooded with water from Delaware Bay, the freshwater vegetation died and the structure of the marsh crumbled. In storms, saltwater followed the old drainage ditch system and flooded low-lying farm fields adjacent to the refuge. The salty water limited the crops that would grow.

Bailey said this restoration project will help property owners to the north in Slaughter Beach, to the south in Prime Hook and Broadkill beaches and also help area farmers.

The $38 million cost includes shifting drainage in several of the refuge marsh units to restore historic channels and allow the marshes to revert back to historic, tidal salt and brackish marshes. Federal officials believe that will make the marsh system more resilient during coastal storms and improve drainage. Salt tolerant grasses will be planted to help the wetlands built and keep pace with sea level.

One of the landmarks in the area – the foundation of a tower that dated back to WWII – now sits several feet offshore in deep water. It will be covered in sand, said Bart Wilson, the project manager for the federal agency.

The plan is to create a 220-foot-wide beach in the area, with a 40-foot wide dune that will taper into the adjacent marsh to the west. The dune will be 9-feet above mean sea level, said Al Rizzo, The Fish & Wildlife Service Coastal Delaware project leader for Bombay Hook and Prime Hook national wildlife refuges. The dune height is based on remnant dunes in the area, he said.

"We're crossing our fingers and praying we don't get a nor'easter or hurricane in the next five years," Rizzo said.

That will give thousands of sprigs of beach grass time to establish on the manmade dune and build resiliency.

The dune will taper into the adjacent marsh.

The area is one of the most dynamic along Delaware's coast. The remains of a bird viewing platform constructed less than a decade ago behind the dune, are now in deep water just off the beach. A series of studies found that manipulation of the area marsh over the last several decades kept it from keeping pace with sea level rise. Many of Delaware's coastal marshes are keeping pace with sea level rise by adding fractions of inches of decomposing plant matter year after year. Those marshes retreat naturally as waves cause the sand to over wash into the wetland and form a new beach just to the west. That didn't happen at Fowler Beach because the adjacent marsh flooded, the plants died and deep inlets were cut over the last several years. Rather than a beach, a mucky layer of exposed peat edged the shoreline.

Hurricane Sandy worsened the damage that had already occurred.

This massive marsh and beach restoration is designed as a demonstration project on coastal and marsh resilience in a refuge system. It is also designed to protect and restore thousands of acres of habitat at the refuge.

Rizzo said the project took two years to design, using sophisticated modeling to guide the marsh drainage work. Earlier this summer, crews started work on a plan to improve the drainage in the marsh system by clearing sand from the network of historic drainage channels.

The beach repairs could be completed as early as this spring with all of the work finished by October 2016, Wilson said.

Rizzo said the sand pumping contract is $14 million. Additional money will be spent to plant the rebuilt dune. The total project cost is $38 million from federal Sandy relief money.

Other repair sites

Delaware's other major Sandy repair projects are mostly complete, save for work on projects at two state wildlife refuges in Kent County.

One of the most iconic images after Hurricane Sandy in Delaware was of the damage at the north side of Indian River Inlet bridge. There, the approach road from the old bridge was destroyed by waves and storm surge – confirming the long-held fear that the old bridge was vulnerable and a new one needed.

Since Sandy, both the approach road and the old bridge have been removed. State transportation contractors removed thousands of cubic yards of sand from the roadway and used it to rebuild the storm-flattened dune. In addition, they pounded steel-sheeting into the sand just east of the roadway to protect it from future storm damage. More sand was pumped from a bar in the inlet onto the north inlet beach to create a wider buffer for the new bridge approach road.

Elsewhere along the ocean coast, sand was pumped in to replace the losses at Rehoboth and Dewey beaches, Bethany and South Bethany and Fenwick Island. Total cost: $30 million.

The state received an additional $6.9 million for habitat restoration along the Delaware Bayshore.

At Mispillion Harbor, where the plan is to rebuild shorebird and horseshoe crab habitat by creating more sandy beach, state officials are ready to apply for state and federal permits.

"The whole point is to improve habitat for spawning horseshoe crabs and red knot" shorebirds, said Karen Bennett, who administers the state's Delaware Bayshore initiative.

The existing rock wall at Mispillion Harbor will be raised three-feet higher than it is now to keep waves and storm high tides from topping it. An area that has breached in the past will be angled into an existing sand dune to prevent future breaching.

The idea is to recreate the habitat in the area as it looked in the 1940s and '50s, said Jeremey Ashe, the restoration project manager.

Small structures perpendicular to the rock wall will be built to help hold the sand in place, he said. The two final parts of the Mispillion project will be to fill an old ditch to create a tidal marsh and try a small, experimental project to create about two acres of shorebird roosting habitat in the old Fitzgerald Marsh to the west of the harbor.

To the north, at Milford Neck, the state, The Nature Conservancy and Delaware Wild Lands are working together to come up with a plan to restore the marsh to a more natural drainage system. Like most tidal wetlands in Delaware, the marshes at Milford Neck were cut with ditches to drain them and reduce mosquito populations.

Bennett said state officials know that coastal storms and flooding are inevitable so the idea with this project is to restore drainage so when flooding does happen, the water doesn't inundate the western edge of the marsh – the buffer between the marsh and the uplands. When that happens, saltwater kills the trees and vegetation, she said.

At the Ted Harvey State Wildlife Area east of Dover, state officials are planning a restoration of the existing impoundment, a manmade structure that holds water during times where birds are migrating through the area. The existing dike between the impoundment and Delaware Bay dates back to the 1960s, Ashe said.

The dike will be raised two to three feet to make it higher and less likely to be breached during coastal storms. A pumping system to raise and lower water levels will also be upgraded.

At Little Creek Wildlife Area, state officials are looking at how to make the impoundments there more storm resilient.The best strategy may be to create a buffer for future sea level rise but modeling work is still underway. The shoreline to the east is no longer a sandy beach and part of a restoration there, Ashe said, might eventually include restoration of a sand shoreline.

As a final state project, state wildlife officials are working with the state Department of Transportation to restore Port Mahon Road. The road ends at a boat launch ramp and parking lot but is especially vulnerable to storm and flood damage.

Federal money to replace lost sand

For beaches alone, this breakdown of federal spending to replace sand losses from Sandy:

509,000 cubic yards at Rehoboth Beach-Dewey Beach -- $9,172,794

440,000 cubic yards at the north side of Indian River Inlet -- $6.6 million

536,000 cubic yards at Bethany-South Bethany -- $7,832,731

368,000 cubic yards at Fenwick Island -- $4,319,254

22,000 cubic yards along the Delaware Bay at Lewes -- $752,420

Source: Army Corps of Engineers

search_result.title: $1M in lagoon grant money may instead go to fix Brevard's beaches
search_result.text:
The Brevard County Commission will vote Tuesday on whether to place a moratorium on a special grant program designed to help the Indian River Lagoon.

The $1 million-a-year "Tourism + Indian River Lagoon Grant Program" is funded by revenue from the county's 5% tourist development tax on hotel rooms and other short-term rentals.

A quarter of the tax money goes into a fund that is used primarily for beach renourishment, though some is also used for such things as the lagoon grants.

Beach damage from Ian, Nicole:Hurricane beach damage exceeds $70 million, wiping out reserve fund

Under a proposal before the County Commission ― which was unanimously approved on Feb. 22 by the advisory Brevard County Tourist Development Council ― the lagoon grant money instead would go toward helping pay to repair damage to Brevard's south beaches caused by Hurricanes Ian and Nicole in 2022. The 14.5-mile south beaches area stretches from Spessard Holland Park south to Sebastian Inlet.

The proposal calls for the grant program to be suspended for the 2023-24 budget year that begins Oct. 1, with no new grant applications accepted.

Previously approved grants for the current 2022-23 budget year would not be affected. In fact, commissioners also are being asked to give nine grant recipients for 2022-23 an extra year to complete their projects.

There was a wide range of projects approved for funding for this year, includes ones dealing with seagrass restoration, improving the clam and oyster populations in the lagoon, and removal of derelict boats from waterways.

Latest estimates indicate that beach repairs in the south beaches for the 2022 storms will total $22.49 million, which will use all beach funds and reserves, plus require an additional $6.44 million to be drawn from federal American Rescue Plan Act funds that the county received. County commissioners approved that ARPA fund allocation on Dec. 6.

County officials are hoping that the Federal Emergency Management Agency, in conjunction with the Florida Division of Emergency Management, will reimburse the county for much of the storm damage work along the south beaches. But FEMA reimbursement could take two to three years.

"We're in a precarious situation, with respect to beach funding," said hotel owner and Tourist Development Council Vice Chair Tom Hermansen, who proposed the moratorium on the lagoon grant program.

Support from Commission Chair Pritchett

Brevard County Commission Chair Rita Pritchett, who also chairs the Tourist Development Council, voted with the other eight TDC members in favor of the change. Pritchett told TDC members that she anticipated there would be County Commission support for the change as well, as that move also has the backing of Brevard County Natural Resources Management Department Director Virginia Barker.

Barker's department received grants for three projects under the program for 2022-23, totaling $549,300.

In a presentation to the TDC, Mike McGarry, beaches, boating and waterways program manager for the Natural Resources Management Department, said most of the south beaches restoration work is expected to be completed in the current budget year. But that area also might require several million dollars more in the 2023-24 budget year for required dune vegetation planting and ongoing environmental monitoring.

The south beaches renourishment work is underway, and will continue through April 30, McGarry said. Any work that remains would begin on Nov. 1. Beach work is halted during turtle nesting season from May 1 through Oct. 31.

Lagoon sales tax update:Lagoon committee OK's millions in cleanup plan

Any action to temporarily suspend the Tourism + Indian River Lagoon Grant Program would have no impact on a much-larger county program to provide money for projects aimed at improving the condition of the lagoon.

That program is funded by a special half-percent Save Our Indian River Lagoon sales tax that was approved by Brevard County voters in 2016. The lagoon tax raises about $50 million a year.

$70 million hit to other beaches

Separately, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers likely will pay for most of the renourishment work on Brevard beaches south of Patrick Space Force Base but north of the south beaches ― sections known as the midreach and south reach.

McGarry said the latest Army Corps of Engineers estimates indicate that those areas sustained about $70 million in total damages from the 2022 storms. That's an increase from a previous estimate of $45 million.

Beach repair work on those areas that total 11.4 miles is expected to take place from November 2023 through April 2024, McGarry said.

Space Coast Office of Tourism Executive Director Peter Cranis said every dollar spent from the tourist tax's beach fund for beach restoration has an average return on investment of $9 from federal and state funding.

In addition, McGarry said beach-related tourism has an more than $1 billion-a-year positive economic impact on the Brevard County.

Ben Malik

Guest columnist

The current Indian River lagoon condition took over 50 years to reach this point. In 2016, Brevard County voters passed a half-penny sales tax increase to assist in cleanup efforts. This tax is expected to generate $340 million over 10 years.

That sounds like a lot of money. But based upon the cost of recent storm water projects, county officials estimate it would cost $1,000 per pound of nitrogen removed — or $1.39 billion — for municipalities along the lagoon to eliminate the 1.39 million pounds the Environmental Protection Agency and the state propose over 15 years from northern Volusia County to the Jupiter Inlet in Palm Beach County.

The cost to cure all of the storm water and sewer plant upgrades will require state and federal funding and I encourage residents to write to their elected officials to support these efforts.

Some state and county officials have called for redirecting some of the Brevard County hotel bed tax funds for infrastructure projects. In simple math this does not come close to solving the lagoon problem.

More:Not again: Dreaded fish kill begins in Brevard

More:Brevard environmental officials prepare for dealing with major fish kill

The bed tax generated $13.6 million last year and these funds are used for promotion of tourism and capital projects related to tourism. Raiding this fund doesn’t solve the gap between the estimated $1.39 billion dollar cost to cure the lagoon. In addition, it will actually hurt the half-penny sales tax fund used for the lagoon as approximately 25 percent of the collected sales taxes are from tourists. Tourist spending equals approximately $10 million in sales tax proceeds. This doesn’t make any economic sense.

We still need to find the exact cause of increased nitrogen in the lagoon. Studies indicate a very direct correlation to human waste as research by Dr. Brian LaPointe at Harbor Branch Oceanographic Institute at Florida Atlantic University points to evidence of sewage-driven eutrophication and harmful algal blooms. We have our very own Dr. Duane DeFreese, director of the Indian River Lagoon Council and fellow waterman and surfer, working in conjunction with Florida Tech and others to solve this problem.

If we desire to solve the problem, let’s look at long-term funding by allocating actual dollar amounts needed to cure the problem.

Brevard County's state Sen. Debbie Mayfield filed Senate Bill 786, which would have annually allocated $50 million for certain projects related to Indian River Lagoon. The bill died in the Senate and a similar Florida House Bill 339 filed by Rep. Gayle Harrell also failed in committee. These bills would have been a start to bridging the estimated $1.39 billion cost to cure. Local cities must look at sewer and wastewater fees to ensure the costs for these services are sufficient to upgrade their plants.

Brevard County taxpayers have stepped up and passed sales tax to help the lagoon. I encourage all the other impacted counties to pass similar measures to solve the problem. Going after the tourism bed tax, which is a vital economic engine in Florida, will not fix the problem. If anything, I would suggest considering an additional penny of tourism bed tax to be set aside for specific infrastructure, beach, safety and capital projects. This potentially generates $3.2 million per year and frees up some funds from county and cities’operating budgets to deal with deferred infrastructure projects.

Clean water has no party affiliation as it is a vital natural and economic interest for all of us. Even if you don’t care about the environment (as a surfer I absolutely do), one should care about the tax revenue generated by waterfront properties and the economic impact of boating, fishing and water recreation activities, which is estimated at over $3.7 billion, according to the EPA.

Ben Malik is the mayor of Cocoa Beach.
